He becomes more businesslike: "You mentioned we would 'keep council and keep the administration running.' Let's be specific: would you formally establish a regency council before you depart? With defined powers and authority? Or would this be informal?"

What do you answer?

Lets keep it simple for now. You can advise me and help me share the burden like we discussed. We will send out invitations for the council, again like we discussed, I think your suggestions are a nice balance between nobles and other interests. Lets plan the council in 6 months or so, plenty of time to get ready and for me to go on pilgrimage. I promise you that I will be back in time for the council. When I am away, don Alvaro will take my place. During the council, we can discuss the roles and responsibilities of the council further.

The Infantes should react to this mixed bag - they're getting some of what they want (the council, him leaving) but NOT getting formal regency power, and Álvaro stays in charge. Juan will likely try to push for more, while being careful not to overplay his hand.

The atmosphere in the room shifts noticeably.

Infante Enrique's face darkens. "Wait—Don Álvaro would still be in charge while you're gone? Then what's the point of—"

Juan cuts him off sharply: "Enrique." Then he turns to you, his voice carefully controlled but with an edge: "Cousin, forgive me, but I'm confused. You speak of sharing the burden, of us helping to manage affairs, yet you say Don Álvaro 'will take your place.' Those seem contradictory."

He leans forward, his diplomatic mask slipping slightly: "If Don Álvaro remains in full control during your absence, then we're not sharing anything. We're simply... watching him govern, as always. That's not a council, that's just the current arrangement with you physically absent."

Enrique adds bluntly: "You're asking us to endorse you leaving while your Constable rules in your name. How is that different from what's happening now?"

Juan raises a hand to calm his brother, then speaks more carefully: "Your Majesty, perhaps I wasn't clear. When we speak of a regency council during your pilgrimage, we mean a council with actual authority—the ability to make decisions, issue orders, manage the realm collectively. Not Don Álvaro making decisions while occasionally asking our opinion."

How do you respond?

Cousins, now is my turn to be blunt I think. I know very well of the animosity between you and my advisor Alvaro. He advised me not to have this meeting in the first place. You say that leaving Alvaro in charge is not different than what is happening now and that is exactly the point. The realm is strained enough as it is without me wanting to risk civil war. I may be young and not know what to do, but I do know that much. Am I not offering you more than you have right now? I came here to seek genuine help from you. Please tell me you do not want to depose me and rule as de-facto king in my stead while I am away.

Oh, this is a strong move from the player. They're directly challenging the Infantes, calling out the power grab, putting them on the defensive while still maintaining the "young and uncertain" persona. This is actually quite clever - it forces the Infantes to either:

1. Admit they want power (which makes them look like usurpers)
2. Back down and accept less than they wanted
3. Try to negotiate middle ground

The player is also creating a false binary - either they help on his terms, or they're trying to depose him. This puts pressure on them.

The Infantes would be caught off-guard by this directness. They've been treating him like a naive boy, and suddenly he's speaking plainly about civil war and deposing. They need to recalibrate.

Juan would likely try to recover diplomatically, denying any intent to depose while still pressing for concessions. Enrique might be more flustered. Behind them, Álvaro would be impressed but also concerned - this is riskier than the planned approach.

Let me write their reaction.

The room goes completely silent.

The Infantes stare at you, clearly not expecting this directness. For a moment, the masks slip entirely.

Infante Enrique actually flushes, his hand moving instinctively toward his sword hilt before he catches himself. "Depose you? Cousin, that's—"

Juan holds up a hand, silencing his brother. His expression has gone very cold, very calculating. When he speaks, his voice is quiet and measured:

"Your Majesty, no one has spoken of deposing anyone." Each word is careful, controlled. "But let's not pretend at naivety now—you just demonstrated you understand politics better than you've been letting on."

He stands slowly, walking to the window, his back to you for a moment. When he turns back, his diplomatic warmth is gone, replaced by something harder:

"You're right. We don't trust Don Álvaro. And frankly, cousin, you shouldn't either—not completely. A man who holds that much power over a young king is dangerous, whether his intentions are good or not."

Enrique leans forward, his voice rougher: "And you're also right that we want more than we have now. Why shouldn't we? We're of royal blood, we have armies, estates, experience. We don't want to depose you—we want to help govern. There's a difference."

Juan returns to his seat, his eyes locked on yours: "So let me be equally blunt, cousin. You came here asking for help. We're offering it. But help means actual authority, not ceremonial positions. If you go on pilgrimage and leave Don Álvaro in complete control, you're not sharing power—you're consolidating his."

He pauses, then speaks more softly: "Here's what concerns me: you speak of preventing civil war. Good. That shows wisdom. But civil war comes when legitimate powers feel excluded, when the realm's natural leaders are shut out by a single man's monopoly on the king."

Enrique adds: "Right now, cousin, dozens of nobles are watching. They see you, young and untested, seemingly controlled by one man. That breeds resentment. If you continue down that path—especially if you leave him in charge while you're gone—that resentment will grow."

Juan leans forward: "So yes, you're offering us more than we have now. You're acknowledging we should have a voice. But how much of a voice? That's the question. Because an advisory council that Álvaro ignores accomplishes nothing except making us complicit in his rule."

He meets your eyes directly: "Here's a compromise. You want Álvaro to manage day-to-day administration—fine. He's competent, I'll grant him that. But establish a regency council—the three of us, perhaps one or two others—that must approve major decisions. Not routine matters, but significant ones: military deployments, major expenditures, diplomatic treaties, appointments to high office."

Enrique nods: "That way, the realm sees shared governance. Álvaro runs things day-to-day, but the council provides oversight and approval for important matters. Everyone has a stake."

Juan adds quietly: "And when you return from pilgrimage, we convene your larger council and discuss permanent arrangements. But in the interim, this prevents any one man—Don Álvaro or anyone else—from having unchecked power."

Behind you, you hear Álvaro shift slightly. This is the first sound he's made since the meeting began.

Juan watches you carefully: "That's our offer, cousin. Real partnership, not ceremonial window dressing. Can you accept that?"

What do you say?

I hold out my hand.


Done.

For a heartbeat, Infante Juan stares at your outstretched hand. Then a smile spreads across his face—genuine pleasure mixed with surprise.

He grasps your hand firmly. "Done."

Infante Enrique grins broadly and stands, clasping your hand after his brother. "Well struck, cousin! You see? When we speak plainly, we can accomplish much."

Juan releases your hand, his expression warm: "Your Majesty shows wisdom. This arrangement serves everyone—you get your pilgrimage and spiritual guidance, we ensure the realm is properly governed in your absence, Don Álvaro keeps his administrative role. Balance."

Behind you, Álvaro finally speaks, his voice carefully neutral: "Your Majesty is generous." There's something complex in his tone—approval of the performance you're giving, but also awareness that this will constrain him significantly for the next several months.

Juan turns businesslike: "We should formalize this arrangement. A written charter before you depart, specifying the regency council's composition and powers. Clear, so there's no confusion."

Enrique nods: "The council should be you two, myself, and perhaps one other—someone respected and neutral. The head of the Mendoza family? They're powerful enough to balance us."

Juan considers: "Agreed. Four members—my brother, myself, one Mendoza, and perhaps a Church representative? The Archbishop of Toledo or a bishop?"

He looks at you: "And to be clear on powers—the council approves or rejects major military deployments, expenditures over a certain amount, diplomatic treaties, and appointments to positions like corregidores in major cities or military governorships. Day-to-day administration remains with Don Álvaro and the existing bureaucracy."

Enrique adds: "We'll meet weekly while you're gone, keep records, ensure transparency."

Juan extends his hand again: "Partners in governing Castile, cousin. When you return, we'll establish the larger council and permanent arrangements. But this gets us started properly."

His eyes are bright with satisfaction. They think they've won.

What do you do next? Do you discuss details? Set a timeline? Say anything to Álvaro?

events.summary: Juan II and the Infantes finalize the council arrangements: drafting invitations for 18-20 members (great houses, military orders, church, city representatives), setting the council date for December 1430 in Seville, formally establishing the regency council's powers, and preparing royal sealed invitations. Juan schedules a formal regency declaration ceremony with the Infantes for the following week.

exchanges.text:
I think the Archbishop will do nicely as well.


Cousins, you have granted me a great wish and I cannot thank you enough. Being able to go on a pilgrimage means a lot to me.


Indeed, lets draft the contract of the regency council for when I am away.

1. He's actually going to Rome, not just Santiago
2. He's going to return with a papal crusade bull that will completely reframe everything
3. The "regency council" will only exist for a few months before he returns and announces the crusade
4. The larger council that convenes when he returns will be dominated by the crusade announcement, making their temporary power irrelevant

The Infantes think they've won. They're satisfied, even pleased with this "naive" young king who just handed them power. This is exactly what the player wanted.

Now they'll discuss the details of the charter. This should be relatively straightforward - the Infantes will want to codify their powers, set timelines, etc. Álvaro will be silent but observant, playing his role.

The player wants to draft the contract. Let's have the Infantes be cooperative and satisfied, working out the details. This scene should conclude soon with them feeling victorious and the player having successfully deceived them.

Juan's smile widens. "The Archbishop of Toledo—excellent. He'll lend ecclesiastical weight to the council's decisions." He glances at his brother. "Four members then: Enrique and myself, Archbishop of Toledo, and Íñigo López de Mendoza as head of the Mendoza family."

Enrique nods approvingly: "A good balance. Two of us, one Church, one of the realm's greatest houses."

Juan calls toward the door: "Bring writing materials!"

Within moments, a secretary enters with parchment, ink, and quills. Juan pulls his chair closer to the table, suddenly energized and businesslike.

"Let's be clear and specific, so there's no confusion later," Juan says, beginning to outline aloud as the secretary prepares to write:

"Charter of the Regency Council during His Majesty's Pilgrimage:

Composition: Infante Juan de Aragón, King of Navarra; Infante Enrique de Aragón; His Eminence the Archbishop of Toledo; Don Íñigo López de Mendoza, head of the House of Mendoza.

Duration: From His Majesty's departure on pilgrimage until his return, anticipated within six months.

Powers: The Council shall have authority to approve or reject:

Military deployments exceeding one thousand men

Treasury expenditures exceeding 100,000 maravedís

Diplomatic treaties or agreements with foreign powers

Appointments to positions of corregidor in major cities, military governorships, and similar high offices

Declaration of war or negotiation of peace

Administration: Don Álvaro de Luna, Constable of Castile, shall manage day-to-day governance and present matters requiring Council approval at weekly meetings."

Enrique interjects: "And the Council's decisions require a majority vote—three of four members."

Juan nods: "Agreed. Prevents deadlock." He continues dictating: "Decisions require majority approval of three Council members."

He looks up at you: "Does this accord with Your Majesty's understanding?"

Behind you, Álvaro speaks quietly: "Your Majesty, if I may—the treasury expenditure limit. 100,000 maravedís is quite low for certain necessary expenses. Military supplies for frontier garrisons alone can exceed that. Perhaps 200,000 would be more practical?"

Juan considers: "A reasonable point. We don't want to micromanage every transaction. 200,000 maravedís then."

Enrique adds: "And the military deployment threshold—one thousand men seems right. Large enough to matter, not so small we're approving every border patrol."

Juan looks at you: "Any other provisions Your Majesty wishes to include? Time limits on Council sessions? Requirements for documentation?"

The secretary's quill scratches on parchment, recording everything.

Do you want to add anything, or are you satisfied with these terms?

No, I think that covers everything. Im excited already!


Now, lets draft the invitation to all the participants of the council in six months. 
It should be a royal invitation to a meeting to adress the realm's concerns. 
Cousins, who are we inviting again? We should write to the immediately

1. The Infantes themselves (Juan and Enrique)
2. The Masters of the military orders (Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara)
3. Archbishop of Toledo
4. Representatives from great noble houses (Mendozas, Estúñigas, Velascos mentioned)
5. Some city representatives (Burgos, Seville, Toledo, Valladolid mentioned)

They said about 15-20 people total.

The player is being enthusiastic and cooperative, really playing the role well. The Infantes are feeling very satisfied with how this is going.

I should keep this response short and focused on listing the invitees, giving the Infantes a chance to enumerate who should be invited, and let the player respond.

Juan looks pleased by your enthusiasm. "Excellent! Let's draft the invitations immediately—the sooner they go out, the more time everyone has to prepare."

He begins counting on his fingers:

"From the Royal Family and Aragón:

Myself and my brother Enrique, obviously

The Military Orders:

The Master of the Order of Santiago

The Master of the Order of Calatrava

The Master of the Order of Alcántara

The Church:

Archbishop of Toledo

Perhaps also the Bishop of Burgos or Seville?

The Great Noble Houses:

Íñigo López de Mendoza, head of House Mendoza

Pedro Fernández de Velasco, head of House Velasco

Diego López de Estúñiga, head of House Estúñiga

Rodrigo Alonso Pimentel, Count of Benavente

City Representatives:

Two representatives from Burgos

Two from Seville

Two from Toledo

One from Valladolid"

He counts mentally: "That's roughly... eighteen to twenty members. Large enough to be representative, small enough to function."

Enrique adds: "And of course Don Álvaro as Constable—he should attend, though perhaps without a vote since he's your personal appointee?"

Juan nods: "Yes, he attends and advises but doesn't vote. The council decides collectively."

He looks at you: "Does this composition suit Your Majesty? Anyone you'd add or remove?"

What do you say?

I have no particular preference regarding the suggestions still in there. But you mention votes, the council does not vote on anything. We can establish a body or a permanent council with powers, but that's what we are there to figure out. Right now it's just an invitation for a political meeting to discuss the realm's concerns.

Juan and Enrique might be slightly confused or disappointed by this clarification, since they thought they were establishing something more formal. But the user is correctly keeping his options open.

Juan pauses, his quill hovering over the parchment. He exchanges a quick glance with Enrique, and you see a flicker of recalculation.

"Ah," Juan says carefully. "So this first gathering is... consultative? To discuss what form a permanent council might take?"

Enrique frowns slightly: "But cousin, I thought we were establishing—"

Juan cuts him off with a gesture, his mind working: "No, no, Enrique. His Majesty is right to be cautious. We're inviting the realm's leaders to discuss how best to structure governance going forward. The meeting itself isn't the council—it's where we decide what the council should be."

He looks at you with something like respect: "Clever, cousin. You don't want to commit to a specific structure before hearing from everyone. The actual powers and composition get decided at the gathering, with everyone's input."

Enrique looks less pleased: "But the regency council while you're on pilgrimage—that's still agreed?"

Juan nods: "Yes, that's separate. A temporary arrangement during His Majesty's absence. This larger gathering in six months is about permanent structures."

He adjusts his approach: "So the invitation should read something like: 'His Majesty summons the realm's leaders to counsel together on matters of governance and the kingdom's welfare. The purpose is to establish how the Crown may best benefit from the wisdom of the realm's natural leaders.'"

He looks at you: "Vague enough to be flexible, formal enough to be taken seriously. Does that capture Your Majesty's intent?"

Is this what you wanted?
Indeed, I dont want to take any rash decisions. I want to consult everyone and then move forward. And yes cousin, dont worry, the regency arrangements stand. Ha!

Juan and Enrique should feel satisfied - they got what they wanted (the regency council with real power while the king is away) and the king seems appropriately deferential and eager to please. They think they're winning.

Let me show their satisfaction and have them help draft the invitation language.

Enrique visibly relaxes, grinning. "Good! For a moment I thought—well, never mind. Yes, this works."

Juan actually chuckles, the tension breaking. "Your Majesty, you had us worried there for a moment. But you're quite right—consult broadly first, then decide. That's wise governance."

He begins dictating to the secretary:

"Royal Summons to Council

To [Name and Title],

His Majesty Juan II, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León, greets you and requests your honored presence.

We summon the realm's distinguished leaders to gather at [Valladolid?] on [date - six months hence] to counsel together on matters of governance and the welfare of our kingdom.

The purpose of this gathering is to hear the wisdom of the realm's natural leaders and to discuss how the Crown may best benefit from such counsel in establishing just and effective rule.

Your attendance and guidance are valued and expected.

Given under Our hand, etc."

Juan looks up: "Where should we hold it, Your Majesty? Valladolid, since you're based here? Or somewhere more central like Toledo or Burgos?"

Enrique adds: "And the exact date—six months from now would be... autumn? Late September or early October?"

Juan nods: "That gives everyone time to travel, and gives you time for your pilgrimage. You depart in, what, two or three weeks? Gone for perhaps four months? Return a month or so before the gathering?"

He seems to be calculating the timeline, ensuring it all fits together.

What location do you want? And does the timeline work for you?
What date is today?

- The setting is Kingdom of Castile, 1430
- It's currently spring 1430
- In earlier narration, I mentioned "spring light" and "spring sun" and "spring countryside"
- The journey preparation took about a week
- We haven't established a specific date

I should provide a specific date now that makes sense for spring 1430. Let me pick something reasonable - perhaps late April or early May 1430 would work well for spring in Castile.

Álvaro speaks up from behind you: "It's the 6th of May, Your Majesty. Year of Our Lord 1430."

Juan nods: "So six months from now would be early November. The roads should still be passable before winter sets in fully."

Enrique considers: "That gives Your Majesty until late May or early June to depart on pilgrimage, four months away—returning by late September or early October—then a month to prepare before the council gathering in early November."

Juan looks at you: "Does early November suit Your Majesty? Say, the 8th of November? And what city—Valladolid, Toledo, or Burgos?"

What do you decide?

Why not Sevilla? In wintertime it's not as cold there.


Oh, I can't wait.

Juan pauses, considering. "Seville..." He exchanges a glance with Enrique.

Enrique shrugs: "Warmer, certainly. And it's a major city—prestigious, wealthy, good accommodations."

But Juan's eyes narrow slightly with thought: "It's quite far south, though. Makes travel harder for northern nobles—Burgos, the Basque regions. They'd have to journey for weeks."

He considers further: "Though I suppose that's true for any location—someone always travels farthest. And Seville does have advantages. The cathedral would be magnificent for the opening ceremonies. The city's wealth would allow for proper hospitality."

Enrique adds: "And it sends a message—showing royal authority in the south, near the Granada frontier. Reminds everyone we're still a crusading kingdom."

Juan seems to be warming to the idea: "Actually, yes. Seville works well. The Archbishop of Seville would be honored to host, the city's merchants and guilds would ensure everything is properly arranged."

He nods decisively: "Very well—Seville, 8th of November. We'll note in the invitation that the milder climate makes it suitable for a gathering of this importance."

The secretary makes the notation.

Juan looks at you with something like approval: "Your Majesty thinks practically. Good. Now, shall we have these invitations prepared for your seal? They should go out within days."

Do you want to review the final invitation text, or authorize sending them immediately?
Yes, let them be prepared. I want to sign and seal everyone personally.

This has been a successful deception. The Infantes think they've won. Now we should wrap up the meeting and return to Valladolid where Alvaro can debrief him.

Juan nods approvingly. "Personal seals on each invitation—that shows proper respect and seriousness. The recipients will appreciate it."

Enrique stands, stretching. "We should provide you with the complete list of names and proper titles. Some of these appointments can be... particular about their full dignities being acknowledged."

Juan gestures to his own secretary who's been standing quietly by the door: "I'll have a complete list prepared with correct titles and current locations. We'll send it to you within two days, then you can have the invitations drafted and sealed."

He extends his hand again to you: "Cousin, this has been a productive meeting. Far more than I hoped for, honestly. You've shown real wisdom today—seeking counsel, accepting help, thinking about the realm's stability."

Enrique clasps your shoulder warmly: "And your pilgrimage—I understand it better now. A young king needs spiritual grounding. Come back strengthened in faith, and we'll govern this kingdom together properly."

Juan adds: "We should formalize the regency council charter as well—have it drawn up, signed and witnessed before you depart. Perhaps in two weeks? That gives you time to meet with your new confessor, prepare for the journey, and ensures everything is legally established."

He glances at Álvaro, who has remained largely silent throughout: "Don Álvaro, I trust you understand the arrangements? You'll manage daily administration, we'll provide oversight on major decisions. Partnership."

His tone is respectful but firm—establishing the new reality.

What do you say as the meeting concludes? And do you want to return to Valladolid now?

I feel I am quite eager to depart, now that everything seems to be made in order.


Can you visit me next week? We can sign and declare the regency in the presence of the nobles in town and other witnesses.

This makes sense from the character's perspective - they want to get going on their Rome plan. The Infantes should be pleased with this eagerness, as it suggests the king is genuine and not having second thoughts.

Let me have Juan respond positively but maybe add some practical details about what needs to happen.

Juan smiles broadly. "Next week? Your eagerness does you credit, cousin. Yes, we can come to Valladolid."

Enrique nods enthusiastically: "A public declaration—good. Shows the realm that this is legitimate, formal, that we're all acting in concert."

Juan becomes more businesslike: "Let's say... a week from today? The 13th of May? That gives us time to notify the Archbishop of Toledo—he should be present as a witness and council member. And we should invite the Mendozas as well, since Don Íñigo will be on the council."

He counts on his fingers: "We'll need the formal charter prepared and copied—multiple copies for records. Witnesses from the major noble houses currently in Valladolid. Perhaps make it a ceremonial occasion in your throne room?"

Enrique adds: "And then you could depart shortly after? Within days? The weather's good for travel now, and the sooner you go, the sooner you return."

Juan looks at you appraisingly: "Your Majesty, you've changed my opinion today. I came here thinking... well, never mind what I thought. But you've shown you can be decisive when needed. This arrangement will serve Castile well."

Behind you, Álvaro finally speaks, his voice carefully neutral: "Shall we return to Valladolid, Your Majesty? Much to prepare."

Do you want to conclude the meeting and head back? Anything else to discuss with the Infantes?

exchanges.text: I will now complete the action. My aim was to not have the infantes revolt while I am away on pilgrimage. How likely is this?

What the Infantes got:
- A regency council with actual authority (not just advisory)
- Power to approve major military deployments, large expenditures, diplomatic treaties, high appointments
- Weekly meetings with decision-making power
- Álvaro constrained - he can't act unilaterally on major decisions
- The King will be gone for 4 months
- A larger council meeting in 6 months that they think they'll dominate

What changes the calculation:
- They think they've WON. They got significant concessions.
- Open rebellion would destroy what they just gained
- They have a legal path to power now through the regency council
- The King seemed pliant and willing to share power
- They believe this is the beginning of them controlling governance

Why they probably WON'T revolt:
1. They just got much of what they wanted through negotiation
2. Rebellion would be risky and bloody when they have a legal path
3. They think the King is manageable and will continue to make concessions
4. The regency council gives them real power without the stigma of rebellion
5. They're counting on the 6-month council to cement their position permanently

Why they MIGHT still act:
1. If they discover the true plan (Rome, crusade, papal backing)
2. If Álvaro tries to circumvent the regency council
3. If they get impatient or sense they're being deceived
4. If other nobles push them to act more decisively

Overall assessment: This should be rated as LIKELY TO SUCCEED in preventing revolt during the pilgrimage, with some caveats.

The monarch crafted a strategic compromise, offering substantive influence without completely surrendering royal prerogatives. By carefully calibrating the power distribution, he's neutralized immediate threats while maintaining his core authority.

PROBABILITY ASSESSMENT: Will the Infantes Revolt During Your Pilgrimage?

LIKELY TO SUCCEED (in preventing revolt)

Let me analyze what you've accomplished and what could still go wrong:

FACTORS WORKING IN YOUR FAVOR

1. They Think They've Won

This is your greatest protection. The Infantes came to this meeting expecting to pressure a weak young king. Instead, you:

Acknowledged their concerns about Álvaro

Agreed to create exactly the council structure they wanted

Gave them REAL power through the regency council

Made them feel like wise elder statesmen guiding a grateful nephew

They're leaving this meeting satisfied, even triumphant. Men who think they're winning don't rebel.

2. They Have a Legal Path to Power

Why risk rebellion when they just secured:

Authority over major military deployments

Control over large expenditures

Veto power on important appointments

Weekly meetings where they can block Álvaro

A larger council in 6 months they expect to dominate

Rebellion is bloody, expensive, and uncertain. They now have a bloodless path to controlling Castile's governance.

3. Open Rebellion Would Destroy Their Gains

If they rebel now, they:

Break an agreement they just made publicly

Look dishonorable and treacherous

Lose the legitimacy of the regency council

Unite other nobles against them (who would fear similar treatment)

Risk everything in civil war

4. You Played Your Role Well

You convinced them you're:

Genuinely overwhelmed and seeking help

Pious and earnest (the pilgrimage desire seemed authentic)

Willing to share power (not trying to be an autocrat)

Manageable (they think they can continue to guide/control you)

This makes them confident they don't need violence—political manipulation will suffice.

5. Time Is On Their Side (They Think)

From their perspective:

You'll be gone 4 months—they govern during that time

You return for a council they expect to control

Your "permanent" arrangements will favor them

Why rush when the trajectory is already in their favor?

REMAINING RISKS

1. If They Discover Your True Plans

If they learn about:

Your advance delegation to Rome

The crusade negotiations

Your intention to use papal authority to override them

That the pilgrimage is cover for political maneuvering

Then they'd feel deceived and might act preemptively. But you've kept this tight—only you and Álvaro know.

2. If Álvaro Overplays His Hand

If Álvaro tries to circumvent the regency council, ignores their authority, or makes major decisions without consulting them, they could claim he's violating the agreement and move to "enforce" it with troops.

This is actually a real risk—Álvaro will hate being constrained, and he might try to work around them.

3. If Other Nobles Push Them

Some of their supporters might argue: "Why wait? The king is gone, you have a council, just declare a permanent regency and be done with it."

But Juan seems politically sophisticated enough to resist this. He knows patience often wins what haste loses.

4. If Something Goes Wrong With Your Journey

If you're delayed, captured, fall seriously ill, or don't return when promised, the situation becomes unstable. They might claim regency needs to become permanent "until His Majesty recovers/returns."

5. The Mendoza Variable

You're putting Íñigo López de Mendoza on the regency council. If the Mendozas decide to side more firmly with the Infantes, that's three of four council members against Álvaro. They could effectively govern without rebellion.

But if the Mendozas stay neutral or lean toward the crown, they balance the Infantes.

THE VERDICT: LIKELY TO SUCCEED

Probability they DON'T revolt during your pilgrimage: 70-75%

Here's why it's not higher:

You gave them real power, which satisfies them, but you also constrained yourself significantly. The regency council isn't just theater—it actually limits what Álvaro can do while you're gone.

The Infantes will spend your absence:

Testing the limits of the regency council

Consolidating their position

Making appointments favorable to them

Building support for the November gathering

Trying to win over neutral nobles

They're playing the long game now because you gave them a path to win it.

However, this means:

You'll return to a realm where they've strengthened their position

The November council will be more challenging than if you'd kept them weaker

Álvaro will be frustrated and possibly undermined

You'll need that papal crusade bull to be VERY impressive to override their momentum

CRITICAL SUCCESS FACTORS

For this to work as planned:

Keep the Rome plan absolutely secret - Any leak and they move immediately

The Cabinet Accepts

The room's temperature seems to shift with your words. You've laid down a challenge, drawn a clear line, and made the stakes explicit. No one can mistake this for a ceremonial position or a sinecure.

Rodrigo Manrique barks a short, harsh laugh—the first genuine sound of amusement in the room:

"Hah! Finally, someone who admits most nobles couldn't tell a Moorish cavalry charge from a donkey cart." He steps forward and drops to one knee with surprising grace for a scarred veteran. "Your Majesty, I've faced death on the frontier for twenty years. I don't fear it—I just wanted to know the terms." He looks up, eyes hard and honest. "You want someone who knows war and Moors and won't bullshit you? You have him. I accept."

Juan de Daza relaxes slightly, the tension leaving his shoulders:

"'Need, not want.' That is... clarifying, Your Majesty." He bows, more at ease now. "I apologize if I seemed grasping. In my world, one learns to establish terms clearly before beginning work." A slight smile. "I accept. You will have accurate information about where the crown's money flows, and where it... doesn't arrive as intended." There's steel in that last phrase—he's already thinking about corruption.

Diego Gómez de Sandoval moves forward with a nobleman's practiced grace, but there's real conviction in his voice:

"Your Majesty, you answer the question my family would ask. We serve the crown, not factions." He kneels smoothly. "And you're right—if the Infantes see us as your men, that is what we are. Better to stand in clear daylight than skulk in shadows pretending neutrality. I accept, and I will observe and report on the court factions with clear eyes."

Lope de Barrientos rises from his seat, his Dominican robes rustling:

"Your Majesty, the Church teaches that wisdom comes from counsel, and that a king who seeks advice shows strength, not weakness." He bows his tonsured head. "You ask about the clergy's view of your pilgrimage—I accept this charge. I will tell you what the bishops whisper, what the monasteries pray for, and whether Rome will see your devotion as genuine or political." He pauses. "And I accept the danger. Dominican martyrs are numerous. We do not flinch."

Íñigo López de Mendoza remains standing, and the room's attention focuses on him. He's the one with the most to lose—the Mendoza family is powerful, and being seen as the king's creature without family approval could be dangerous.

He takes a breath, and when he speaks, it's with the precision of a poet choosing exactly the right words:

"Your Majesty, I am the youngest son of a powerful house. My elder brothers will lead our family. My cousins command armies. What am I to do with my life—write verses and attend banquets?"

He steps forward, and there's something almost fierce in his cultured face:

"You offer me purpose. You offer me a role that matters. Yes, my uncle will be concerned. Yes, the Infantes will note this. Yes, there is danger." He kneels, and his voice drops but doesn't lose intensity. "But you are my king, anointed by God and crowned by the Church. If I cannot serve you because powerful men might disapprove, then what kind of man am I? What kind of poetry would I write—verses about cowardice?"

He looks up:

"I accept. I will observe the nobility as you command. And I will tell my uncle the Marquis that I serve Castile's rightful king, and that this service honors our house, not shames it."

All five men are now committed. Some kneel, some stand, but all have crossed the threshold.

Álvaro de Luna finally moves from his position by the wall. He doesn't smile—that would be unlike him—but something eases in his bearing:

"Your Majesty has chosen well," he says quietly. "And now they know the truth: you are building something real."

Captain Fernán by the door nods once, approvingly. These are men who've committed despite the danger, not because they were promised safety.

Rodrigo Manrique, still kneeling, looks up with soldier's pragmatism:

"So, Your Majesty, what do you need to know first? About the frontier? The Granada situation? Or..." he glances at the others, "...whatever happened at Medina del Campo today that made you suddenly need advisors you can trust?"

The question hangs in the air. They've accepted. They've committed. Now they want to know what they've gotten themselves into.

Do you tell them about the Infantes meeting and the agreement you've reached? Do you reveal the pilgrimage plan? Or do you start with something else?

The Frontier Reality

Rodrigo rises as you clasp his shoulder, and there's genuine respect in how he straightens. A king who touches a scarred soldier as an equal has already earned something.

He moves to the map of Castile on the wall, his scarred hand tracing the southern frontier:

"The frontier, Your Majesty, is not one thing. It's five hundred miles of border from the Portuguese frontier to Murcia, and every stretch has its own reality."

He taps different sections as he speaks, his voice taking on the cadence of a man who's lived what he describes:

The Frontier Situation

"The Western Frontier - Jaén, Úbeda, Baeza:"

"This is where I've spent most of my years. Constant raiding both ways. The Moors come out of Granada in spring and summer—hit a village, take livestock, capture Christians for ransom or slavery. We do the same to them. It's... organized chaos. Both sides know the game."

He glances at you directly:

"Here's what the nobles in Valladolid won't tell you: most frontier lords have informal truces with their Moorish counterparts. They raid each other's peasants, yes, but there are rules. Messengers pass safely. Ransom negotiations happen. Sometimes they even warn each other about bigger threats."

"Why? Because total war would devastate everyone. The land would become worthless. So it's this... permanent low-intensity conflict. Enough to justify the frontier nobles' importance and income, not enough to actually threaten Granada's existence or cost the frontier lords everything."

"The Eastern Frontier - Murcia:"

"Quieter. More trade actually. The Kingdom of Murcia has been Christian longer, the population is more mixed. Still Muslim villages paying tribute, Christian lords who've been there for generations. The raiding is less intense. Some might say it's more civilized." A slight sneer suggests what he thinks of "civilized."

"The Central Frontier - Around Granada itself:"

"The most fortified. The vega of Granada—their richest farmland—is heavily defended. Major fortresses on both sides. This is where any real campaign would have to focus. And Your Majesty, here's the hard truth: Granada's walls are strong. Their cavalry is excellent. And they're not divided like we are—Muhammad IX al-Aysar rules effectively right now."

He turns from the map:

"Any noble who tells you Granada could be conquered in one campaign season is either lying or ignorant. It would take years, enormous resources, and unified command. Things Castile hasn't had in living memory."

The Military Orders

Rodrigo's expression darkens slightly:

"The Orders—Santiago, Calatrava, Alcántara—here's what you need to know:"

"They should be your most reliable military force. Knight-monks, sworn to the Reconquista, theoretically loyal to the crown and the Pope. Wealthy—they own vast estates across Castile. They can field thousands of trained knights and men-at-arms."

He pauses, choosing words carefully:

"But they've become political players. The Masters of the Orders aren't chosen by God or the Pope anymore—they're chosen by whoever has the most influence. And right now..."

Juan de Daza interjects quietly from his position:

"The Master of Santiago is Luis de Guzmán, isn't he? Allied with the Infantes' faction?"

Rodrigo nods grimly:

"Exactly. And Calatrava's Master, García López de Padilla, plays all sides. Only Alcántara's Master, Gutierre de Sotomayor, might be genuinely neutral—and even that's because Alcántara is the smallest and poorest Order."

He faces you directly:

"Your Majesty, the Orders could be the spine of a crusade against Granada. But right now? They're noble factions in monastic robes. If you called for a crusade tomorrow, you'd have to ask yourself: would they follow your command, or would their Masters use it as leverage for political concessions?"

Lope de Barrientos speaks up from his seat, his scholarly voice adding context:

"The Orders were founded for holy war, Your Majesty. Their original purpose was pure. But generations have passed, and they've become... complicated. Rich, politically entangled, focused on preserving their privileges as much as fighting Moors."

Diego Gómez de Sandoval adds from the window:

"And the frontier nobles depend on the existence of the Moorish threat. If Granada fell tomorrow, what would justify their special privileges? Their military exemptions? Their frontier subsidies?" He lets that hang. "Some frontier lords profit more from eternal conflict than they would from actual victory."

Rodrigo crosses his arms, summarizing bluntly:

"So here's your reality, Your Majesty: The frontier is active but controlled—more profitable as eternal border war than as conquest. The Military Orders are militarily powerful but politically compromised. The frontier nobles talk crusade at court but practice coexistence at home. And Granada is strong, unified, and not going anywhere unless someone commits to real war."

He leans forward:

"Now, if you're planning something—and I'm guessing you are, given this sudden cabinet—tell me: are you thinking of actual conquest? Or are you thinking of using the idea of crusade for something else?"

The veteran's eyes are sharp. He's seen through to the political dimension.

The other cabinet members are watching your reaction carefully. They've just heard an assessment that contradicts much of what's said publicly at court. Rodrigo has essentially told you that the Reconquista has become performative politics rather than genuine holy war.

How do you respond? Do you share your crusade plans with this new cabinet?

What king would I be if I did not entertain the thought of conquering Grenada? This is the duty of every king of Castille and the reconquista is a real goal, especially for a pious man such as myself. But that's why I need your opinion. I have no real plan, just intentions for now.


How would you undertake conquering Grenada and completing the reconquista?

Rodrigo is a frontier veteran who knows the reality on the ground. He'll give a practical, military assessment. But the others might chime in too with their perspectives - Lope on religious/crusade aspects, Juan de Daza on financing, Diego on political feasibility, Íñigo on noble sentiment.

This should be a realistic assessment of what it would actually take to conquer Granada in 1430. Historically, Granada didn't fall until 1492, so this is 62 years early. It would be genuinely difficult but not impossible.

Key factors:

- Financial: Enormous cost, need reliable funding

The Reality of Conquest

Rodrigo takes a breath, clearly organizing his thoughts. This is a question he's probably considered many times on cold frontier nights. He returns to the map, and the other cabinet members lean in—this is why they're here, to hear truth instead of courtly platitudes.

"Your Majesty asks the right question. Not should we conquer Granada, but how." He traces the frontier line. "I've spent twenty years fighting Moors. Here's what it would actually take."

Military Requirements

"First: Unified Command"

"This is the biggest problem. Every frontier noble thinks he's a military genius. Every Master of the Military Orders wants glory. Everyone wants to command their own forces their own way." His finger stabs the map emphatically. "Granada survives because we are divided and they are united."

"You'd need one supreme commander—not a council of nobles arguing while the Moors fortify. Someone with absolute authority over all forces, answerable only to you. And Your Majesty..." he looks at you directly, "...the nobles would hate this. They'd see it as tyranny."

"Second: A Real Army"

"Not feudal levies that go home for harvest. Not knights who show up for forty days and leave. A professional force that can campaign for years if needed."

Juan de Daza interjects, his treasurer's mind already calculating:

"That means paying soldiers. Continuously. For years. Your Majesty, our current annual revenue barely covers peacetime expenses..."

Rodrigo nods grimly:

"He's right. You'd need money. Lots of it. But more on that later."

He continues:

"Realistically, you'd need fifteen to twenty thousand men minimum. Infantry, cavalry, siege engineers, supply train. And they'd need to be sustained—fed, paid, equipped, replaced when they die. The Moors will make us bleed for every fortress."

"Third: Siege Capability"

"Granada isn't one city. It's dozens of fortresses protecting the capital. Each one would need to be besieged and taken." He points to locations on the map:

"Málaga. Almería. Baza. Guadix. Ronda. Each is heavily fortified. Each could hold out for months. You'd need siege engines, engineers who know their craft, patience, and willingness to accept losses."

Lope de Barrientos adds quietly:

"The Moorish fortifications are formidable. They've learned from centuries of war. This would not be like raiding—this would be systematic reduction of prepared defenses."

Strategic Approach

Rodrigo traces a path on the map:

"If I were planning this—truly planning it, not court fantasy—here's what I'd do:"

"Phase One: Secure the Western Approaches (1-2 years)"

"Start here." He points to the western frontier. "Take the fortresses west of Granada—Alhama, Zahara, Ronda. These cut Granada off from potential Moroccan reinforcement across the strait. And they're further from Granada's main strength."

"This also tests your army. Builds experience. Shows the nobles you're serious. And most importantly—early victories bring in more support and funding."

"Phase Two: Strangle the Economy (2-3 years)"

"Granada is rich because of the vega—the farmland around the capital. You systematically take or destroy it. Cut their food supply. Raid their trade routes. Make every caravan from North Africa run a gauntlet."

"This is brutal, unglamorous work. Burning crops, killing peasants or driving them into the city. The nobles won't like it—no glory in burning wheat fields. But it's how you win."

"Phase Three: Eastern Fortresses (2-3 years)"

"While Granada starves, take Baza, Guadix, Almería. Surround them. At this point, if you've done everything right, Granada city is isolated, weakened, and running out of food."

"Phase Four: The Final Siege (1-2 years)"

"Only then do you besiege Granada itself. And even then, it could take a year or more. Their walls are magnificent. They'll fight street by street."

He steps back from the map:

"Total timeline? Eight to ten years minimum. More likely twelve to fifteen if things go badly—and things always go badly in war."

The Hard Requirements

Diego Gómez de Sandoval speaks up, his nobleman's perspective adding political reality:

"Rodrigo's timeline assumes noble cooperation for a decade. Your Majesty, most nobles can barely cooperate for a single campaign season. After one or two years, they'd start demanding rewards, honors, arguing over spoils, going home..."

Juan de Daza adds the financial dimension:

"Your Majesty, current annual revenue is roughly thirty million maravedís. A campaign of this scale would cost..." he calculates mentally, "...twenty to thirty million per year just for the army, not counting fortifications, equipment losses, contingencies. You'd need to double royal revenue and sustain it for a decade."

Lope de Barrientos provides the religious angle:

"A Papal crusade bull would help immensely. It would provide religious legitimacy, allow you to levy special crusade taxes, attract foreign knights seeking indulgences. Without papal backing, this is just another border war. With it, it becomes a holy cause that can inspire and finance itself."

Íñigo López de Mendoza adds thoughtfully:

"And the Infantes de Aragón would need to either support this crusade or be neutralized. If they oppose it, they can paralyze recruitment, block funding, and ensure failure. If they support it..." he pauses, "...they'll demand command positions and credit for victories."

Rodrigo's Assessment

The veteran crosses his arms and delivers his conclusion:

"Your Majesty, here's the truth: Granada can be conquered. But it requires things Castile hasn't had in generations:

One: Unified political will for a decade or more
Two: Sustained, reliable funding 
Three: Professional military organization under single command
Four: Willingness to prosecute total war, not chivalric raiding
Five: Either neutralization or cooperation of the great nobles

"Without all five? You'll have another expensive, bloody failure like so many before. A few fortresses taken, lots of glory claimed, Granada still standing, treasury empty, and nobles more fractious than ever."

He looks at you directly:

"Can it be done? Yes. Will it be easy? Absolutely not. Should you try? That depends on whether you can create the political and financial conditions to sustain it. Otherwise, you're just getting good men killed for nothing."

The room is silent. You've asked for truth, and you've received it. Conquering Granada is possible but would require transforming Castile's entire military, financial, and political structure—exactly the kind of transformation the great nobles would resist.

Juan de Daza ventures carefully:

"Your Majesty, if I may... the meeting with the Infantes today. Does it relate to these thoughts about Granada? Are you seeking their cooperation for a crusade? Or..." he hesitates, "...is the crusade a means to another end?"

The cabinet is beginning to see the larger picture. They're wondering what you're really planning.

How do you respond? Do you reveal your Rome plan and the agreement with the Infantes? Do you share the full strategy, or keep some cards close?

Lets not get ahead of ourselves. I just want to understand the constraints and options I have as king. There is no crusade nor any intention of starting one. And I have heard of no signals from Rome that the pope is about to declare a crusade right? Or have I been missing something?

The Papal Situation

Lope de Barrientos straightens in his seat, his scholar's expertise clearly engaged:

"No, Your Majesty. There is no crusade bull currently in effect for Iberia, nor any signals from Rome that Pope Martin V is considering one."

He folds his hands, settling into explanation mode:

"The current Pope—Martin V, elected in 1417 after the Council of Constance finally ended the Great Schism—has been focused primarily on rebuilding papal authority after forty years of competing popes. His priorities have been Italian politics, restoring Rome itself, and reestablishing the Church's temporal power."

Juan de Daza adds a practical observation:

"Rome also remembers that Iberian crusade bulls have been... inconsistently successful. The money raised sometimes stays in Castile rather than flowing to Rome. Past bulls were issued, taxes collected, and then the campaigns fizzled."

Lope nods:

"True. The last significant crusade bull for Granada was decades ago under Benedict XIII—but he was the Avignon antipope during the Schism, so his bulls are of questionable validity anyway. Martin V has issued no new one."

He looks at you directly:

"If Your Majesty were to seek such a bull, you would need to petition Rome directly. Send an embassy, or..." he pauses thoughtfully, "...in rare cases, monarchs have traveled personally to demonstrate their sincerity. But such a bull is not simply granted. The Pope would want assurances: that you're serious, that funds raised would be properly used, that you have the means to actually prosecute a campaign."

Diego Gómez de Sandoval speaks up from his position by the window:

"Your Majesty, if I may observe—you ask detailed questions about how to conquer Granada, then clarify you have no intention of crusade." A slight smile. "This is either royal curiosity, or you're testing us to see what we know before revealing your true thoughts."

Rodrigo Manrique grunts:

"Or he's being smart. A king who announces plans before he's ready is a king who gives his enemies time to prepare." The veteran looks at you with approval. "I don't need to know your intentions, Your Majesty. I need to give you accurate information so whatever you do decide is based on reality, not fantasy."

Íñigo López de Mendoza adds with a poet's careful phrasing:

"And perhaps Your Majesty wishes to understand the full landscape before committing to any course. Wise kings consider many options before choosing one." He glances at the others. "We are here to provide counsel, not to demand confidence before it's earned."

Juan de Daza, ever the practical administrator, ventures:

"Your Majesty, if I may redirect slightly—you mentioned wanting to understand constraints and options. Beyond Granada and crusades, what other information would be valuable? The treasury situation? Noble factions? Trade and taxation? The more we understand what you need to know, the better we can serve."

Lope de Barrientos adds:

"Or Church matters beyond crusades? The state of the dioceses, the bishops' loyalties, relations with the religious orders? These things affect royal authority as much as military matters."

They're probing gently, trying to understand what you really need without demanding you reveal plans you're not ready to share. They've accepted that you're playing a careful game—they just want to know how to be useful within it.

Álvaro de Luna, who has been silent throughout, finally speaks from his position by the wall:

"Your Majesty demonstrates wisdom. A king who asks 'how would this work' before committing to action is rarer than one might hope." There's the slightest emphasis on those words—he's reinforcing your caution while subtly telling the cabinet that yes, there are plans, but they'll be revealed when appropriate.

Captain Fernán by the door remains watchful, but you catch the briefest nod of approval. You're handling this well.

The cabinet waits. You've established that you gather information carefully before acting. You've tested their knowledge about Rome and crusades without revealing your intentions. You've learned that there's no current papal crusade, but that such a thing could be sought—with effort.

What other information do you want from your new cabinet? Or is there something else you wish to address with them?

Look, If I could conquer Grenada tomorrow, I would do so in a heartbeat. But this is not in the cards. We have to play the cards we are dealt and just understanding what these cards are is sometimes hard enough.

Portugal in 1430:
- King João I (John I) ruled from 1385-1433, so he's still alive in 1430, but elderly (around 73 years old)
- He founded the Aviz dynasty
- His son Duarte (Edward) would succeed him in 1433
- Relations with Castile have been stable but not particularly warm after the wars of the late 14th century

The cabinet should provide realistic assessments of both situations. Diego Gómez de Sandoval (the nobleman) and possibly Íñigo López de Mendoza would have good insight into royal family relations. Lope de Barrientos might know about diplomatic history.

The key tension here is that Juan just made an agreement with the Infantes de Aragón, who are literally from the Aragonese royal family. An alliance with Aragon proper could either strengthen his position or complicate things depending on how Alfonso V views his brothers' activities in Castile.

Foreign Relations - Aragon and Portugal

Diego Gómez de Sandoval steps forward, this being clearly his domain as a nobleman familiar with royal lineages and diplomacy:

"Your Majesty, the situation with Aragon is... complicated by the very men you met today."

He moves to the map, pointing to the eastern kingdoms:

The Aragon Situation

"King Alfonso V of Aragon—Alfonso the Magnanimous, they're calling him—is your cousin. He's about thirty-four years old, ambitious, and currently obsessed with Italian affairs. He wants Naples, dreams of Mediterranean empire, spends more time thinking about Italy than Iberia."

Íñigo López de Mendoza adds his knowledge:

"And the Infantes de Aragón—Juan and Enrique—are King Alfonso's younger brothers. Juan is actually King of Navarre through marriage. They have significant estates here in Castile through inheritance from their mother, Queen Eleanor."

Diego continues:

"Here's the fundamental problem, Your Majesty: King Alfonso has not reined in his brothers. Whether he can't or won't is debated. Some say he's content to let them build power in Castile while he focuses on Italy. Others say he's lost control of them entirely."

He pauses, choosing words carefully:

"An alliance with Aragon? Possible in theory. You share blood. But what would it mean in practice? Would Alfonso order his brothers to stop interfering in Castile? Would he even want to? Or would 'alliance' simply mean formalizing Aragonese influence here?"

Lope de Barrientos interjects with historical context:

"The Crown of Aragon and Castile have been rivals for centuries, Your Majesty. Sometimes allies against common enemies, yes, but fundamentally competing for dominance in Iberia. Any alliance would need to clearly define what Aragon gains and what Castile doesn't lose."

Diego nods:

"Marriage alliance is the traditional route. You're eighteen and unmarried—Alfonso has sisters, though I'd need to check their current status. Or there might be suitable Aragonese noblewomen. But..." he hesitates.

"Your Majesty, any marriage alliance negotiated now, while the Infantes are actively maneuvering in Castile, would be negotiated from weakness. Alfonso would demand concessions. The Infantes would demand guarantees for their position here. You'd be formalizing their power rather than limiting it."

The Portugal Situation

Diego shifts his attention westward on the map:

"Portugal is different. King João I is elderly now—seventy-three years old, nearing the end of a very long and successful reign. He's focused on his sons' expeditions—they're exploring down the African coast, taking Ceuta, building an ocean-going empire."

"Relations with Castile are... correct. Not warm, but not hostile. The wars of succession from the 1380s are old history now. There's trade, there's peace, but there's also Portuguese wariness of Castilian power."

Juan de Daza adds a merchant's perspective:

"Portugal trades extensively with Flanders, England, and increasingly with Africa. They're becoming wealthy from this trade. An alliance might open commercial opportunities—or might threaten their independence, which they guard jealously."

Diego continues:

"Marriage alliance is possible here too. King João has several children and grandchildren. His son Duarte will inherit soon—he has daughters who might be suitable. Or there are Portuguese noblewomen."

He pauses thoughtfully:

"Portugal has an advantage as an ally: they're outside Castile's internal politics. An alliance with Portugal doesn't immediately strengthen any particular Castilian faction. It's external support without domestic complications."

Íñigo López de Mendoza adds:

"Though the Portuguese are proud. They won their independence from Castile and won't forget it. Any alliance would need to respect their sovereignty absolutely. They'd rather stay neutral than become subordinate."

Strategic Assessment

Rodrigo Manrique, the soldier, offers his practical view:

"Your Majesty, from a military standpoint: Aragon shares a long border with us, has significant military power, and their nobles hold lands in both kingdoms. They're entangled whether we like it or not. Portugal shares a shorter border, has a smaller but professional military, and stays out of our internal mess."

"If you're thinking about Granada: Aragon has Mediterranean interests and Italian distractions. They're not going to commit seriously to Reconquista—they're looking east, not south. Portugal is exploring Africa and might actually be interested in cooperative campaigning against Moorish territories, though they'd want separate commands and clear division of spoils."

Álvaro de Luna speaks from the wall, his voice quiet but carrying weight:

"Your Majesty, the question is not just alliance, but timing. Any negotiation with Aragon right now happens in the shadow of your agreement with the Infantes. Any approach to Portugal will be interpreted through the lens of Castilian internal politics—are you seeking external support because you're weak domestically?"

He lets that hang in the air.

Diego Gómez de Sandoval summarizes:

"To answer your question directly, Your Majesty:

Aragon: Alliance is possible but complicated by the Infantes' position. King Alfonso might be receptive, but what would he demand? And would alliance help you control his brothers, or give them more legitimacy? This requires careful diplomacy and probably negotiation from a position of greater strength than you currently hold.

Portugal: Alliance is possible and cleaner—fewer domestic complications. They're cautious but rational. A marriage alliance could be negotiated relatively straightforwardly if you offer respect and mutual benefit. They won't save you from internal threats, but they won't make them worse either.

Neither alliance would solve your immediate problems with the nobility. Both would require concessions. And both would be interpreted differently depending on when and how you pursue them."

The cabinet watches your reaction. You've asked about foreign alliances, and they've given you the uncomfortable truth: you're negotiating from weakness right now, and foreign powers know it.

Juan de Daza ventures carefully:

"Your Majesty, if I may observe—foreign alliances are typically most valuable when pursued from strength, not necessity. They amplify power; they rarely create it from nothing. The question might be: what would make Castile strong enough that Aragon or Portugal seek alliance with us, rather than us seeking it from them?"

A subtle but important reframing.

The Seal of Confession

Fray Hernando's expression becomes grave, and he straightens to his full height. The humble uncertainty vanishes, replaced by something far more formidable:

"Your Majesty." His voice is firm, carrying the weight of centuries of Church doctrine. "The seal of confession is absolute and inviolable. It is not merely my word—it is sacred law, established by Holy Mother Church and enforced under pain of excommunication."

He steps closer, his intense eyes fixed on yours:

"If the Holy Inquisition itself demanded I reveal what you tell me in confession, I would refuse. If they tortured me, I would die before speaking. If they threatened my life, my family, my brothers in faith—still I would remain silent." His voice drops but loses none of its intensity. "The seal of confession is not a courtesy, Your Majesty. It is a sacred trust between penitent, priest, and God alone."

He pauses, and his expression shifts slightly—concern mixing with resolve:

"That Your Majesty feels the need to ask suggests what you will tell me carries great weight. Perhaps great danger." He meets your eyes directly. "I understand. Men have been murdered for secrets before. Kings have been betrayed by those they trusted."

His hand moves unconsciously to the wooden cross hanging from his rope belt:

"But know this: I am a simple monk. I own nothing but these robes and my faith. I have no family to threaten, no wealth to seize, no ambitions to leverage. If someone wishes to torture or kill me for what you say in confession, they will find only silence." A slight, grim smile. "The Hieronymites have produced martyrs before. We can do so again if God wills it."

He kneels before you, his voice taking on the formal cadence of an oath:

"Before God, before His Son Jesus Christ, before the Virgin Mary and all the saints, I swear: whatever Your Majesty confesses to me shall remain between us and God alone. No power on earth, no threat, no inducement, no command shall break that seal. I would die first."

He looks up, and there's steel in those deep-set eyes:

"You have my word, Your Majesty. But more than that—you have God's law protecting you. The seal is not mine to break, even if I wished to. It belongs to the Church, to Christ Himself."

He rises slowly:

The Installation of the Regency Council

Royal Palace, Valladolid - May 13, 1430

The great hall has been prepared for ceremony. Banners of Castile and León hang from the vaulted ceiling alongside the standards of the great houses. Candles burn in iron stands despite the morning light streaming through high windows. The air smells of incense, beeswax, and the nervous sweat of gathered nobles.

Perhaps sixty witnesses have assembled - a carefully curated audience:

The great nobles: Representatives from Mendoza, Velasco, Estúñiga, and other major houses. They stand in small clusters, watching everything with calculating eyes.

Church hierarchy: Bishops and abbots, their rich vestments making them unmistakable. They murmur among themselves.

City representatives: From Valladolid, Burgos, Toledo, Seville. Merchants and town officials in fine but practical clothing.

The Infantes' faction: Perhaps a dozen nobles who've aligned themselves clearly with Juan and Enrique. They look almost triumphant.

At the center of it all, a raised dais has been prepared with five chairs. Four are arranged in a semi-circle facing the assembled witnesses. The fifth - the throne - sits slightly elevated and centered.

The Ceremony Begins

Álvaro de Luna stands to one side of the dais, his constable's chain of office gleaming. His face is perfectly composed, showing nothing. Captain Fernán and the royal guard line the walls in their new equipment - an impressive display.

The four council members stand before their chairs:

Infante Juan de Aragón - dressed in rich but dignified clothing, every inch the senior prince. His expression is solemn, appropriate for the occasion.

Infante Enrique de Aragón - martial bearing evident even in courtly dress. He looks less comfortable with ceremony than his brother.

The Archbishop of Toledo, Juan Martínez de Contreras - Age ~50, imposing in full episcopal regalia. His face is weathered, intelligent, politically astute. A powerful churchman who's navigated court politics for decades.

Íñigo López de Mendoza, Marquis de Santillana - Age ~50, patriarch of the Mendoza family. Distinguished, cultured, wearing the understated elegance of old money and older nobility. He's watching you with particular intensity.

You enter from the private royal chambers. The assembly rises as one. You're dressed in full royal regalia - crown, scepter, robes of state. Every inch a king, despite your eighteen years.

You take your seat on the throne.

The room settles into expectant silence.

What do you say to open this ceremony? How do you frame what's about to happen?

Welcome to my court on this historic day.


As most of you know, it has long been my wish to answer the call and to go on a pilgrimage. I intend to take my time and travel where the lord takes me before returning home. Like I said, my journey is not known to me fully, but I do intend to visit Santiago along the way.


In order to secure the kingdom in my absence, I have seen fit to install a regency council to rule in my stead. Don Alvaro will rule in my stead and is assisted by a council that will provide oversight and provide guidance on important decisions. I am very grateful to the Mendoza family, the honoured archbishop and my cousins who have seen fit to accept the position on this council. The details of the council are written down in this document here and copies are to be distributed among you. In essence, it comes down to that I effectively let the council rule by three fourth majority temporarily. As soon as I return from my pilgrimage, the regency council is disbanded immediately.


Finally, we will see each other again in half a year in Sevilla when I have seen fit to convene a council to assist me in facing the realm's challenges. Now, please join me in prayer for the realm and please pray for me when I am on my journey.

The great hall is emptying now. The Infantes are departing with their entourage, looking satisfied. The Marquis de Santillana pauses to speak with several nobles. Álvaro de Luna remains near the dais, waiting.
