Fray Hernando steps forward, his expression deeply troubled.

"Your Majesty, may I speak?" At your nod, he continues carefully. "I understand your anger at the Infantes' rebellion. What they did was treasonous. But..." He glances at María, then back to you. "Is this justice or is this vengeance? And more practically - is this wise?"

He clasps his hands together.

"You said in Florence that Christian virtue should guide your crusaders. One of those virtues is prudence - acting wisely, not rashly. Another is mercy toward those who might yet repent." He pauses. "The Infantes rebelled and failed. They're humiliated and weakened. In November, you could confront them at the Royal Council with all the nobles watching, with the papal bull in hand, with the weight of Rome behind you. You could force them to bend the knee publicly or be condemned by everyone present."

His voice grows more urgent.

"But if you order their arrest now, from hundreds of miles away, you turn a failed rebellion into a desperate fight for survival. You give them no choice but total resistance. And you risk splitting Castile into armed camps right when you need unity for the crusade."

He meets your eyes.

"I'm not saying they don't deserve punishment. I'm asking - is this the right moment? Is this the right method? Or are you acting from wounded pride rather than strategic calculation?"

María has been silent, but now she speaks quietly:

"I'm grateful you want to keep me out of it, hermano. Truly. But Fray Hernando is right - this could tear everything apart. And..." She hesitates. "If Captain Fernán leaves, and something happens to you here while he's gone, I would never forgive myself."

All three of them are watching you, waiting.

What do you do? Do you proceed with sending Captain Fernán? Modify your orders? Reconsider entirely?

I am touched by your concerns. Captain shall have my written letter and seal. He shall not travel alone, a small company that can travel quickly should be enough.


We must draw upon those we have encountered on the road and wanted to join the crusade more than ever. We have facilitated those promising men who lack the funds to travel to Sevilla. Have any of them reached Barcelona yet? If so, I may expand our company in Barcelona with a handful of crusaders, swelling our numbers enough to make up for those we have sent away. Fray, your task begins sooner than expected to make sure the crusade adheres to christian values and commits to confession.


I know this action may seem risky to you, but those travelling with me for some time know that I sometimes have a feeling that something is the right thing to do. I have the same feeling now. I know this action may trigger rebellion or even civil war. But I believe that in the end, we will come out stronger. And rest assured that they will recieve fair trial and that I will be merciful when the time comes.

María will be distressed but accept this is his decision. Fray Hernando will be troubled but accept his role. Captain Fernán will follow orders but be concerned. The practical arrangements need to be made.

This action (sending the arrest orders) will need a probability assessment and dice roll eventually. But first, let me handle the immediate scene.

Captain Fernán exchanges a glance with Fray Hernando, then nods slowly.

"As you command, Your Majesty. I'll take three good riders - fast horses, light armor, able to fight if necessary but focused on speed. Two weeks to Valladolid if we push hard, less if fortune favors us."

Fray Hernando closes his eyes briefly, as if in prayer, then opens them.

"Then I will begin as you've asked. I'll speak with any crusaders who arrive, hear their confessions, assess their spiritual readiness." His voice is heavy with concern. "And I will pray, Your Majesty. Pray that your feeling proves true. That this doesn't ignite the civil war we all fear."

María stands, her face pale but composed.

"I still think this is dangerous, hermano. But you're the king. It's your decision." She wipes her eyes. "I'll help however I can. If you need men from Barcelona, I'll see what can be arranged discreetly."

Captain Fernán moves toward the door. "I'll begin preparations immediately. We'll need supplies for the journey, fresh horses, and..." He pauses. "Your Majesty, I'll need that written order soon. The sooner I depart, the sooner this reaches Don Álvaro."

As if on cue, there's a knock at the door. One of your guards - Felipe - enters and bows.

"Your Majesty, there are visitors in the palace courtyard. Four men just arrived from the road - Italians by their look and speech. They're asking for the King of Castile. They say they heard your speech in Florence and have come to join the crusade."

He looks uncertain. "Pere de Cardona's men are keeping them in the courtyard, but they seem... eager. Legitimate. One of them speaks some Castilian."

Captain Fernán's eyebrows rise slightly. "Quick work. It's only been ten days since Florence. These must be men who dropped everything and rode hard."

He looks at you. "Do you want to see them now? Or shall I assess them first while you draft your letter?"

What do you do? See the Italian arrivals yourself? Have Captain Fernán assess them? Focus on writing the letter first?

Captain, start your preparations for your journey now. Inform those you want to take with you. And appoint the new captain of our company. Who shall take your place when you leave? Rodrigo? Or has Sir Thomas impressed you so? Finally, I want you to judge these new 4 crusaders's martial prowess before you go. Can you do that? If Hernando judges them to be pure of spirit, I shall accept them as the first crusaders of the last reconquista.

Captain Fernán straightens, his military mind already working through the logistics.

"Yes, Your Majesty. I can do all of that." He pauses, thinking aloud. "For my traveling company, I'll take Martín and Felipe - both are good riders, reliable in a fight, and won't slow us down. That leaves you with Sergeant García, Corporal Rodrigo, Sir Thomas, and Peter. Six men if you count Diego your secretary, though he's not really a fighter."

He rubs his jaw thoughtfully.

"As for who commands in my absence..." He looks between you and the others. "Sergeant García is the most experienced soldier - he's served longer than any of us, fought on the frontier, knows his business. But he's not an officer. Never has been. He takes orders well; giving them is different."

He turns slightly toward where you know Sir Thomas is lodging nearby.

"Sir Thomas Beaumont is a knight. He's led men in France, commanded small units in the field. He has the bearing, the experience of command. But..." Fernán hesitates. "He's foreign. English. The men respect him, but he's been with us less than three months. And frankly, Your Majesty, I don't know him as well as I know García and Rodrigo."

He meets your eyes directly.

"My recommendation? Make Rodrigo the acting captain. He's young for it - only twenty-six - but he's proven. Loyal beyond question. Smart enough to know when to ask advice. And the men already follow him naturally. García can serve as his sergeant, providing experience. Sir Thomas can serve as your military advisor - he has knowledge we lack, especially about fighting in pitched battles rather than frontier skirmishes."

He nods, as if confirming his own judgment.

"That gives you a proper command structure. Rodrigo leads day-to-day, García provides experience and steadiness, Sir Thomas offers tactical counsel. It should hold together for the few weeks until I return."

He glances toward the door.

"As for the four Italians - yes, I can assess them this afternoon. Give me an hour with them. I'll see how they handle themselves with weapons, ask them about their experience, judge if they're serious or just adventure-seekers. Then Fray Hernando can have them for confession."

He pauses, then adds more quietly:

"Your Majesty, about the letter to Don Álvaro. You should write it now, while I'm making preparations. The sooner I have it in hand, the sooner I can depart. Tomorrow morning at dawn, if all goes well."

María speaks up softly: "I can arrange for your horses and supplies through the palace stables. No one will question it - knights come and go all the time. Your departure won't attract unusual attention."

Captain Fernán bows. "Then with your leave, Your Majesty, I'll begin. I'll have the Italians ready for assessment within the hour."

Do you approve his plan? And will you draft the letter to Álvaro now?

We will do as so. Sister, lets look at my banner and what I carry with them. I want you to see first for yourself what we carry before I ask you to display it. Fray, prepare the writing tools to draft the letter could you?


We go to the banner. Who is guarding it?

Fray Hernando nods and moves to the writing desk, gathering parchment, ink, and quills. "I'll have everything ready, Your Majesty."

Captain Fernán departs to begin his preparations, his footsteps echoing down the corridor.

You lead María to the main chamber where the banner case and reliquary chest rest. Sergeant García and Corporal Rodrigo stand at attention on either side - García's weathered face alert, Rodrigo's younger features focused. They've been on watch since you arrived.

"Your Majesty," García acknowledges with a bow. He nods respectfully to María. "Your Majesty, the Queen."

The long wooden case containing the banner rests against the wall, its iron bands gleaming in the afternoon light from the window. The smaller chest with the reliquaries sits nearby, locked and secured.

María looks at the cases with curiosity mixed with apprehension. "May I?" she asks softly.

At your nod, Rodrigo moves to unlock the banner case. The latches click open. Together, he and García carefully lift out the rolled white silk banner, still in its protective wrapping.

"Shall we unfurl it, Your Majesty?" Rodrigo asks.

The chamber is large enough, though it will take both guards to hold the banner properly - it's twelve feet tall and eight feet wide.

María watches, her hands clasped before her, clearly both eager and slightly nervous to see what has all of Italy talking.

Do you have them unfurl the banner? And then show her the reliquaries?

I wanted to show her the relics. She just have to take our word for it that the banner looks magnificent.


Sister, these are the most holy relics in all of christendom.


I stand back respectfully, not wanting to come too close.


Sister, these men have sworn to guard these relics with their life. Being allowed to come near them and see them is a great honour and something I can grant you as king and instrument of the holy see. A small pleasure I take for myself, selfish as I am. But I want to see the joy on your face when you see these relics for myself. I have touched these relics once when I accepted them and will do so never again. You can look at them up close.


I stand behind Maria and lay my hands on her shoulders.


Steel yourself my sister before you are to see a piece of the cross Jesus himself was crusified on.


I look to the two guards and ask them: "Will you allow my sister to look at the relics for a moment?"

1. The guards' response - they're loyal to Juan, but he's asking them formally, acknowledging their sacred duty
2. María's reaction - she's deeply Catholic, she's been isolated and lonely, this is an intensely spiritual moment
3. The relics themselves - gold and silver reliquaries, the actual fragments inside
4. The emotional weight of the scene

Juan is being very respectful, almost theatrical in his reverence. He's touched them once and vows never again. This is consistent with his character development - the mix of genuine piety and awareness of symbolism.

María should be deeply moved by this. It's not just the relics themselves, but her brother trusting her with this, the intimacy of the moment, the weight of what he's undertaking.

The guards would grant permission - Juan is their king, and this is his sister. But they'd do it solemnly, maintaining the gravity.

García and Rodrigo exchange a brief glance. Then García, the older sergeant, straightens and speaks with unexpected formality:

"Your Majesty has entrusted us with this sacred charge. The relics are under the King's authority, and through him, the Holy See's." He bows his head slightly. "If His Majesty wishes the Queen to see them, then it is permitted."

Rodrigo adds quietly, "It would be an honor to show Her Majesty what we guard."

They move to the reliquary chest. Rodrigo produces the key from around his neck, unlocks it, and carefully lifts the lid.

Inside, nestled in velvet padding, rest two reliquaries:

The gold reliquary - perhaps eight inches tall, ornately worked with religious scenes, set with small gems. Through a crystal window in the front, you can see it: a small fragment of dark wood, no longer than a man's thumb, mounted in a cross of gold wire.

The silver reliquary - slightly smaller, more austere in design but beautifully crafted. Through its crystal face: a single finger bone, yellowed with age, resting on white silk.

María's hands fly to her mouth. She takes a step forward, then stops, as if afraid to get too close. Your hands rest on her shoulders, steadying her.

"Dios mío," she whispers. "That's... that's truly..."

She can't finish the sentence. Tears begin streaming down her face.

Rodrigo carefully lifts the gold reliquary from its velvet nest and holds it at chest height, allowing María to see it clearly. The afternoon light through the window catches the gold, making it seem to glow.

María slowly sinks to her knees, her hands still at her mouth, sobbing quietly. She stares at the dark fragment of wood through her tears.

"The True Cross," she whispers. "The cross where Our Lord died for our sins. Juan... you're carrying this?"

She looks up at you, then back at the reliquary, then back to you. Her face shows wonder, fear, joy, and something like awe all at once.

"No wonder..." she says through her tears. "No wonder the Pope blessed you. No wonder Florence erupted. If you march with this..." She shakes her head, unable to articulate it.

García gently lifts the silver reliquary. "And the blessed Saint James, Your Majesty. Santiago himself, patron of Spain, who brings victory to Christian armies."

María makes the sign of the cross, her hands trembling. She leans closer to the gold reliquary, close enough that her breath might fog the crystal if she weren't holding it carefully.

"May I..." she whispers to the guards, not to you. "May I pray before it? Just for a moment?"

Rodrigo glances at you for confirmation, then nods. He kneels, holding the reliquary steady at a height where María can see it clearly while she prays.

Your sister closes her eyes, clasps her hands, and begins to pray in Latin. Her voice is barely audible, but you catch fragments: "...Domine Jesu Christe... qui pro nobis in cruce..." (Lord Jesus Christ... who for us on the cross...)

She prays for perhaps two minutes - it feels both very long and very brief. When she finishes, she opens her eyes, looks at the reliquary one more time with something like desperate love, then makes the sign of the cross again and rises shakily to her feet.

She turns to you, and suddenly embraces you tightly, burying her face in your shoulder. You can feel her shaking.

"I understand now," she says into your shoulder. "I understand everything. Why you're so certain. Why you feel called. Juan, you're carrying the cross itself. How could you fail with that blessing you?"

She pulls back, wiping her face with her hands, not caring about the tears or her appearance.

"Yes," she says firmly. "Yes, we'll display them in the cathedral. All of Barcelona needs to see this. All of Catalonia. Let them see what you carry. Let them understand that this isn't politics or ambition - this is holy."

She looks back at the reliquaries as García and Rodrigo carefully return them to their velvet nest and close the chest.

"Thank you," she says to the guards. "For showing me. For guarding them so faithfully." Then to you: "And thank you, hermano. For trusting me with this. For letting me see..."

She can't finish. She just embraces you again.

After a long moment, she composes herself and steps back.

"I'll arrange everything. The cathedral display, the meetings with the Archbishop and the Consell. They need to see this. They need to understand." She wipes her eyes once more. "But first... you should write that letter to Álvaro. And I should let you work."

She moves toward the door, then pauses and looks back.

"God is with you, Juan. I felt it in that room just now. Whatever happens with the Infantes, whatever challenges come - God is with you."

She departs, leaving you with Fray Hernando at the writing desk, ready to draft your letter to Álvaro de Luna.

What do you want the letter to say?

events.summary: Juan drafts the arrest letter to Álvaro with Hernando's help, softening language about divine certainty. He then formally accepts the four Italian crusaders in a dawn ceremony before the banner and relics — tapping each with his father's sword and allowing them to touch the reliquaries once. The oath includes unprecedented provisions: no rape, no forced conversion, protect surrendered Muslims with their lives. Juan reorganizes his force: Rodrigo as captain, García as senior sergeant, and establishes rotating banner guard pairs. He plans to recruit promising soldiers and tasks Fray Hernando with assessing all recruits spiritually.

exchanges.text:
I tell Hernando to write the letter with the following direction:


Dear Alvaro,


I am currently in Barcelona after getting incredible support from the pope for myself and our crusade. I carry holy relics with me and seek to present those and the papal bull at the meeting in Sevilla.

The four Italians watch this exchange, understanding from tone and gesture if not from words that Fray Hernando has spoken in their favor. Marco stands straighter. Pietro wipes his eyes. Giovanni clutches his rosary. Andrea looks both terrified and determined.

Rodrigo, standing nearby in his new captain's sword belt, watches intently. García and the other guards have formed up to witness. Sir Thomas observes with professional interest. A few palace servants have gathered at the edges of the courtyard, drawn by the unusual morning assembly.

What do you do? How do you formally accept them as crusaders?

I will accept them into my crusade.


I send for my guards to bring the banner with relics attached to be brought out and unfurled.


In my best Italian, I tell them.


I grant you the possibility to be soldiers of Christ and to be part of our crusade against Grenada. The pope himself charged me with this sacred mission and gave me these two relics so they may be carried against the heathens. I touched them once upon accepting this charge and I grant every soldier of Christ the same grace. You have already spoken with my confessor and I expect you to continue to do so for as long as you remain a soldier of christ in the crusade.


When you become part of the crusade, you accept me as your only commander and you will follow no other orders except from me or from those I put in command.


You commit to behave in accordance with christian values and virtues. No raping or forced conversions. Those muslims who surrender will be treated fairly. Not only will you not commit these acts yourself, but you also swear to prevent others from doing so. When I see surrendered muslims that are about to be shamelessly executed by those who call themselves true christians, I would defend these muslims with my life and I expect you to do the same. We are all sinners, but we swear to fight where we can for justice, mercy and compassion. That is what it truly means to be a soldier of Christ.


Andrea, do you understand what you are about to commit to?


If he accepts, I draw my sword and tap him on the shoulder. I accept you Andrea as the very first crusader and soldier of Christ in my crusade to retake Grenada. You may now for the first and last time in your life on this earth touch the relics that you will help carry towards Grenada.

1. The guards will bring out the banner with relics attached
2. Juan speaks in Italian (his best attempt)
3. He lays out the terms clearly - Christian values, no rape, no forced conversions, protection of surrendered Muslims
4. He specifically asks Andrea (the youngest, most uncertain) if he understands
5. He uses his sword to tap Andrea's shoulder in a knighting/crusader ceremony
6. He allows Andrea to touch the relics as a first and last time

This is significant because:
- Juan is establishing the moral framework for his crusade
- He's making a statement about protecting Muslim prisoners (very unusual for the era)
- He's creating a solemn ceremony that will be remembered
- He's showing real leadership in defining what his crusade will be

I should describe:
- The banner being brought out and unfurled
- The crowd's reaction
- Andrea's response to being singled out
- The touching of the relics
- Then presumably the same ceremony for the other three
- The witnesses' reactions to this unusual oath

Let me write this scene with appropriate gravity and detail.

You gesture to García and Rodrigo. They understand immediately and move swiftly back into the palace. The courtyard falls silent in anticipation.

When they return, they carry the long wooden case between them carefully. They set it down and open the latches. Together, with reverent precision, they lift out the great white banner - already unfurled and with both reliquaries mounted as they were in Florence.

The morning sun catches the pure white silk and it seems to glow. The gold reliquary with the True Cross fragment blazes in the light. The silver reliquary with Santiago's bone gleams below it. Even those who've seen it before - Sir Thomas, Fray Hernando, your guards - draw in their breath.

The four Italians stare in wonder. Pietro falls to his knees spontaneously. Giovanni makes the sign of the cross over and over, tears already streaming down his weathered face.

García and Rodrigo hold the banner upright between them, the white silk moving gently in the morning breeze.

You speak in your careful Italian, your voice carrying across the courtyard:

"I grant you the possibility to be soldiers of Christ and to be part of our crusade against Granada. The Pope himself charged me with this sacred mission and gave me these two relics so they may be carried against the heathens."

You gesture toward the banner.

"I touched them once upon accepting this charge, and I grant every soldier of Christ the same grace. You have already spoken with my confessor and I expect you to continue to do so for as long as you remain a soldier of Christ in the crusade."

Your voice grows more serious, more commanding.

"When you become part of the crusade, you accept me as your only commander and you will follow no other orders except from me or from those I put in command."

You pause, letting this sink in, then continue with particular emphasis:

"You commit to behave in accordance with Christian values and virtues. No raping or forced conversions. Those Muslims who surrender will be treated fairly. Not only will you not commit these acts yourself, but you also swear to prevent others from doing so."

Around the courtyard, several palace servants exchange glances. This is unusual. Most crusade oaths speak of destroying the infidel, not protecting them.

"When I see surrendered Muslims that are about to be shamelessly executed by those who call themselves true Christians, I would defend these Muslims with my life and I expect you to do the same."

Your voice rings with conviction.

"We are all sinners, but we swear to fight where we can for justice, mercy and compassion. That is what it truly means to be a soldier of Christ."

You turn specifically to Andrea, the youngest, the farm boy who looks terrified and awed in equal measure.

"Andrea, do you understand what you are about to commit to?"

Andrea swallows hard. His hands twist his cap. For a long moment he's silent, and you wonder if he'll flee. Then he drops to his knees, his voice cracking but clear enough to hear:

"Sì, Vostra Maestà. Capisco." (Yes, Your Majesty. I understand.) He struggles with the words, then adds in simpler Italian: "I serve you. I serve Cristo. I protect... even Muslims who surrender. I be... I try to be good soldier of Christ."

His grammar is rough, his understanding perhaps incomplete, but his sincerity is absolute.

You draw your father's sword - the blade that bears the inscription Non Nobis Domine. The sound of steel leaving the scabbard is sharp in the quiet morning.

You step forward and tap Andrea gently on his right shoulder with the flat of the blade, then his left shoulder.

"I accept you, Andrea Vescovi, as the very first crusader and soldier of Christ in my crusade to retake Granada."

Andrea's breath catches. Tears stream down his young face.

"You may now, for the first and last time in your life on this earth, touch the relics that you will help carry toward Granada."

García and Rodrigo lower the banner carefully, bringing the reliquaries to a height where Andrea can reach them while kneeling.

Andrea stares at the gold reliquary containing the fragment of the True Cross. His hand trembles as he extends it. He touches the gold housing with just his fingertips, barely making contact, as if afraid he might damage it or isn't worthy. His lips move in silent prayer.

Then he touches the silver reliquary with Santiago's bone. His whole body shakes with emotion.

He remains there for perhaps thirty seconds, his rough farmer's hand resting gently on the sacred vessels, tears falling freely onto the cobblestones beneath him.

Finally he withdraws his hand, makes the sign of the cross, and looks up at you with an expression of such pure devotion that even hardened soldiers around the courtyard look away, overcome.

You help him to his feet. He can barely stand, his legs weak with emotion.

You turn to the other three. "Who is next?"

Marco the mercenary steps forward without hesitation. He kneels with a soldier's practiced grace, his weathered face showing something you haven't seen there before - hope mixed with humility.

He speaks his oath in clear Italian, his voice steady: "I understand, Your Majesty. I have killed for money. I have done shameful things. But I swear before God and these holy relics - I will follow your orders alone. I will protect the innocent. I will be a soldier of Christ, not of mammon. This I swear."

You tap his shoulders with your sword. "I accept you, Marco Tornesi, as a crusader and soldier of Christ."

Marco touches the relics firmly, confidently, like a man finally finding something solid to hold onto after years of drifting. When he rises, he salutes you with fist to heart - but then adds a bow of genuine respect that no mercenary would give for mere pay.

Pietro the merchant's son practically leaps forward, then remembers himself and drops to his knees more decorously. His youthful face shines with excitement and religious fervor.

"Your Majesty, I swear it all! I will follow you! I will be virtuous! I will protect even Muslims who surrender!" His enthusiasm makes several guards smile despite the solemnity. "I will be the best crusader I can be! I swear before God and Santiago!"

You tap his shoulders. "I accept you, Pietro Aldobrandini, as a crusader and soldier of Christ."

Pietro touches the relics and immediately begins weeping and praying loudly in Italian, thanking God, thanking you, thanking Santiago. After several moments, Fray Hernando gently touches his shoulder, and Pietro reluctantly rises, still sniffling.

Giovanni the blacksmith limps forward last. He drops heavily to both knees with a grunt, his injured leg unable to manage a graceful kneel. His three-fingered hand clutches his rosary.

His Italian is rough, working-class, but clear: "Maestà, I am old. I am broken. But I am strong still. I fight for Cristo. I follow you. I protect who you say protect. I die if I must. This is good. This is..." He struggles for words, then simply says, "This is what I want. To do good thing before I die."

You tap his shoulders. "I accept you, Giovanni Rossi, as a crusader and soldier of Christ."

Giovanni touches the relics with both his good hand and his damaged one, pressing them against the gold and silver as if trying to absorb their holiness through his skin. He prays in simple, repetitive phrases - thanking God, asking for strength, promising to serve. When he rises, he has to brace against the banner pole to stand, but his face shows peace.

The ceremony is complete. Four men have become crusaders - the first of what you hope will be thousands.

Fray Hernando steps forward and raises his hands, blessing the four new crusaders in Latin. Then he switches to Italian:

"You are soldiers of Christ now. You serve God through His anointed king. You carry the holy relics toward Granada. This is sacred work. Remember your oaths. Confess your sins regularly. Take communion. Live as Christians, fight as Christians, and if God wills it, die as Christians knowing your souls are saved."

Around the courtyard, witnesses have multiplied. More palace servants, several of María's ladies, guards from the royal palace, even a few early-rising Barcelona citizens who heard something unusual was happening. They've watched this entire ceremony.

One of the palace guards - an Aragonese soldier - murmurs to his companion in Catalan, just loud enough for you to overhear: "Did he just swear to defend surrendered Moors? That's... unusual."

His companion responds: "Unusual? It's unprecedented. But did you see those men's faces? They believed every word."

Rodrigo, your new captain, stands watching with his hand on his sword. You see him reassessing the four Italians - no longer just potential recruits, but now sworn crusaders under his protection and command.

Sir Thomas approaches and speaks quietly in Latin so the Italians won't understand: "Your Majesty, that oath about protecting surrendered Muslims... it's noble, but it will cause problems. Soldiers in the heat of battle, or after seeing their friends killed... they won't want to show mercy. You'll need iron discipline to enforce that."

García, the veteran sergeant, adds his perspective: "But if you can enforce it, Your Majesty, you'll build an army different from any other. Men will know they serve something higher than blood and plunder."

The four new crusaders stand together now, Andrea still wiping his eyes, Pietro grinning despite his tears, Giovanni gripping his rosary, Marco standing with military bearing but softer eyes than he had an hour ago.

The white banner with its sacred relics stands between García and Rodrigo, catching the morning sun, visible to everyone in the courtyard and anyone looking down from palace windows above.

What do you do now? Address the assembled witnesses? Speak to your new crusaders about their duties? Have the banner returned to its case? Something else?

Now we need to reorganize the guard of the banner and the relics. Captain Rodrigo can no longer perform guard duties now that he is captain.


How many royal guards are left in our company? What soldiers are in our company?

Originally in Juan's party when they left Rome (10 people):
1. Juan II
2. Captain Fernán Alonso de Robles (commander) - DEPARTED with letter to Álvaro
3. Fray Hernando de Talavera (confessor)
4. Sergeant García (proven loyal guard)
5. Corporal Rodrigo (proven loyal guard) - NOW ACTING CAPTAIN
6. Martín (guard) - DEPARTED with Captain Fernán
7. Felipe (guard) - DEPARTED with Captain Fernán
8. Diego (secretary) - not a fighter
9. Sir Thomas Beaumont (English knight)
10. Peter (Sir Thomas's squire)

So three people departed: Captain Fernán, Martín, Felipe

That leaves:
- Juan II (king)
- Fray Hernando (confessor, not a fighter)
- García (sergeant, experienced soldier)
- Rodrigo (now acting captain, was a guard)
- Diego (secretary, not a fighter)
- Sir Thomas (knight, experienced soldier)
- Peter (squire, can fight but young)

Royal guards specifically: García and Rodrigo are the original royal guards. But Rodrigo is now captain so shouldn't be doing regular guard rotations.

Just added:
- Marco Tornesi (mercenary, experienced soldier)
- Pietro Aldobrandini (merchant's son, inexperienced)
- Giovanni Rossi (blacksmith, old and injured but willing)
- Andrea Vescovi (farm boy, inexperienced)

So for actual fighters/guards:
- García (experienced royal guard)
- Sir Thomas (experienced knight)
- Peter (squire, some combat ability)
- Marco (experienced mercenary)
- Pietro (inexperienced but enthusiastic)
- Giovanni (limited by age and injury)
- Andrea (raw and inexperienced)

Rodrigo as captain oversees but shouldn't be in regular rotation.

The defensive lineup looks critically undermanned. With only a handful of truly capable fighters, protecting valuable cargo seems precarious. The mix of experienced soldiers and untrained recruits creates significant vulnerabilities in their security arrangement.

Rodrigo steps forward at your question, clearly already thinking through this same issue. He glances around at the assembled group, counting.

"Your Majesty, we're thin on experienced men now." He ticks off on his fingers. "García is our only remaining royal guard with proper training. Sir Thomas is a knight with combat experience. Peter his squire has some skill. Diego is your secretary - he can use a knife but he's not a soldier."

He looks at the four new crusaders.

"Marco has mercenary experience - he's a real fighter. But Pietro, Giovanni, and Andrea..." He pauses diplomatically. "They need training before they can be trusted with guarding the relics alone."

García adds his gruff assessment: "The boy Andrea is strong but green as spring grass. Pietro the merchant has enthusiasm but no discipline yet. Giovanni the smith has spirit but he's old and lame - in a real fight, he'd be a liability more than an asset."

Sir Thomas steps forward, speaking in Latin so the Italians won't understand: "Your Majesty, by my count you have three reliable fighters besides yourself: García, myself, and Marco. Peter can serve adequately. The other three Italians need weeks of training before I'd trust them in combat."

He pauses, then continues: "For guarding the relics and treasury, I suggest rotating pairs. García and Marco together - the veteran and the professional. Sir Thomas and Peter. That gives you two solid teams. The three inexperienced Italians can stand watch during daylight in safe locations, but not at night or in uncertain situations."

Rodrigo nods agreement. "That's sound, Your Majesty. And I'll oversee everything as captain, ready to respond if there's trouble. But you're right - I can't be in regular guard rotation and command effectively."

He looks concerned. "Your Majesty, forgive my bluntness, but we're stretched thin. Captain Fernán, Martín, and Felipe are gone. That's three experienced soldiers. We've added four men, but only one is combat-ready. Until the others are trained..."

García adds: "We're adequate for Barcelona - it's a safe city, we're in the royal palace. But if we face real danger on the road or in hostile territory, we'll be vulnerable. We need more trained men, Your Majesty. Proper soldiers, not enthusiastic boys and old smiths."

The four new crusaders stand nearby, understanding from tone if not words that they're being assessed and found wanting in some ways. Marco stands straight, clearly confident in his abilities. Pietro looks slightly deflated. Giovanni seems unbothered - he knows his limitations. Andrea just looks confused.

How do you want to organize the guard rotations? And do you plan to recruit more soldiers while in Barcelona?

We will secure the banner with the rotating pairs we just discussed. Rodrigo, make sure our new recruits are adequately equipped and armed. The sooner we can get them in proper arms, the sooner will they will get accustomed to it. Let them train.


There is something else we need to consider. We had planned to travel to Sevilla by boat, but with all the activity in Grenada, Im not sure the Grenada coast is safe for us. What do you think captain? Or should we travel by land?

Rodrigo's face grows serious as he considers your question. He glances at Sir Thomas and García, then back to you.

"Your Majesty, that's... a significant concern." He shifts his weight. "I hadn't fully considered the naval threat. But you're right - if Granada has been mobilizing and receiving support from North Africa as the rumors suggest..."

Sir Thomas steps forward, his expression thoughtful. "Your Majesty, the sea route is normally faster - perhaps a week from Barcelona to Seville by galley with good winds. The land route through Aragon and into Castile would take three weeks, possibly four if we encounter difficulties."

He pauses, clearly weighing options.

"But the Mediterranean has become more dangerous if Granada has war galleys active. And corsairs..." He frowns. "They'd love to capture a ship carrying the King of Castile, not to mention holy relics and a fortune in crusade funds. Even a well-armed merchant galley could be overwhelmed by multiple war galleys working together."

García adds his gruff perspective: "On land, Your Majesty, we can see threats coming. We can choose our route, avoid dangerous areas, camp where we want. On a ship, if we're spotted and pursued, there's nowhere to run. We're trapped on a wooden box in the middle of the sea."

He scratches his beard. "But land travel through Aragon... that means passing through territory where the Infantes have influence. Through areas where your enemies might have sympathizers. Word of your route could leak, and ambushes could be prepared."

Rodrigo weighs in: "With only seven capable fighters - counting you, Your Majesty - we're vulnerable either way. On a ship, we're dependent on the crew and captain. On land, we can at least control our own defense, but we're exposed to bandits, hostile nobles, or worse."

Sir Thomas adds: "There's also the matter of time, Your Majesty. You have the Royal Council in Seville on November 8th. It's now August 19th. You wanted to spend two to three weeks here in Barcelona building support. That puts us departing Barcelona in early September. Three to four weeks overland means arriving in Seville in late September or early October - giving you a month to prepare before the Council. That's adequate but not generous."

He continues: "By sea, you'd arrive mid-September with six weeks to prepare. That extra time could be valuable for coordinating with Don Álvaro, meeting with supporters, planning your presentation of the crusade bull."

Rodrigo looks uncomfortable giving advice on such a weighty decision so soon after assuming command, but he tries: "Your Majesty, perhaps... could we gather more intelligence first? Your sister might know the current state of Granada's naval activity. Are their galleys actively patrolling? Have there been recent attacks on Christian shipping? That information would help us decide."

García nods. "And we could hire local guides who know the land routes - which roads are safest, which areas to avoid. Get a better sense of the actual dangers before committing."

Sir Thomas adds: "We could also consider a mixed approach - travel overland through Aragon to the Castilian border, then reassess. If the situation seems safe, we could take ship from Valencia or Cartagena for just the final leg. That reduces sea exposure while still saving some time."

All three men look at you, waiting for your decision or guidance. The four new Italian crusaders watch without understanding the discussion, but sensing its importance.

From a palace window above, you catch a glimpse of movement - someone watching. One of María's ladies, perhaps, or palace servants observing the foreign king and his deliberations.

What do you decide? Gather more intelligence first? Choose a route now? Consider the mixed approach?

events.summary: The Barcelona cathedral campaign is a great success. Over a week, massive crowds come to see the True Cross and Saint James bone. Recruitment system established: physical assessment by Rodrigo and Sir Thomas, spiritual assessment by Fray Hernando. By August 27: 82,000 florins raised (including 20,000 from converso merchant Rodrigo Ruiz, 8,000 from shipping magnate Lorenzo Medina), 62 crusaders recruited and training. The Archbishop of Zaragoza endorses the crusade and argues before the Consell Reial for Aragonese support. The Consell grants safe passage, allows recruitment, and provides 3 ships for transport to Seville. At a dinner hosted by María, Juan meets Isabel Ruiz, the 17-year-old converso merchant's daughter who challenges him about protecting Muslims — and falls deeply in love.

exchanges.text: I want to introduce a challenge for Juan in the form of a common girl for which he develops feelings. This could be a lesser noble woman, a servant or a handmaiden or friend of his sister. Draft six possible persons so I can randomly decide which one will catch his eye.

1 - Catalina de Cardona

Age: 20

Status: Daughter of Pere de Cardona (the Royal Chamberlain who greeted you at the docks), minor Catalan nobility

Position: One of Queen María's ladies-in-waiting

Appearance: Dark-haired, olive-skinned, elegant bearing, intelligent eyes

Personality: Educated, well-read, speaks Latin and Castilian fluently. Witty and perceptive. Questions assumptions politely but persistently.

Challenge: Politically appropriate match, but would tie Juan to Catalan nobility and complicate his independence. Her father serves Alfonso V, creating potential conflict of interest.

Hook: She's fascinated by Juan's spiritual journey but skeptical of certainty - echoes Fray Hernando's concerns in a different voice.

2 - Isabel Ruiz

Age: 17

Status: Daughter of a wealthy Barcelona merchant (converso - Jewish convert to Christianity)

Position: Friend of María's, occasionally at court for social events

Appearance: Auburn hair (unusual), pale skin, freckles, bright green eyes

Personality: Passionate about faith, having grown up in a converso family constantly proving their Christianity. Earnest, idealistic, sees Juan as embodiment of true Christian virtue.

Challenge: Converso background would be controversial among nobility. Her idealization of Juan might be uncomfortable - she sees him as nearly saintly.

Hook: Her family could provide financial backing for the crusade, but romance would be seen as marrying "beneath" his station.

3 - Beatriz Álvarez

Age: 19

Status: Impoverished distant relation of the Mendoza family

Position: María's handmaiden, essentially a servant though technically noble blood

Appearance: Pretty in a simple way, brown hair usually hidden under a servant's cap, warm brown eyes, work-roughened hands

Personality: Quiet, observant, surprisingly educated (taught to read by a kindly priest). Devout but practical. Sees through pretense.

Challenge: Far too low status for a king. Any relationship would be scandalous. Would be seen as Juan using his power inappropriately.

Hook: She witnessed his ceremony with the crusaders and was moved to tears. She embodies the common people's faith he spoke about in Florence.

4 - Leonor de Montcada

Age: 22

Status: Daughter of one of Catalonia's most powerful families

Position: Widow (married at 16, husband died a year ago in Italian wars), now living with Queen María

Appearance: Striking rather than beautiful, tall, dark eyes that have seen grief, dresses in subdued colors

Personality: Mature beyond her years, melancholic but not broken. Intelligent, politically astute. Understands loss and duty.

Challenge: Politically powerful match - Montcada support would be valuable but comes with strings. She's older than Juan and might dominate the relationship. Some whisper she's unlucky (young widow).

Hook: She understands the weight of duty and sacrifice in ways most don't. Their conversations could be profound but also dangerous to his certainty.

5 - Margarita "Margot" Ferrer

Age: 18

Status: Apothecary's daughter from Barcelona's merchant quarter

Position: Sometimes delivers medicines to the palace, no formal court position

Appearance: Blonde (unusual in Spain), blue eyes, practical clothing, often smells faintly of herbs

Personality: Sharp-minded, educated in medicine and herbs by her father. Skeptical of nobility but curious about the world. Speaks bluntly, unimpressed by titles.

Challenge: Common-born, completely inappropriate match. She'd challenge his assumptions constantly. Romance would be pure scandal.

Hook: She might be called to palace if someone falls ill. Her practical, no-nonsense approach to life contrasts sharply with Juan's spiritual intensity. She'd question whether certainty is faith or pride.

6 - Sister Teresa María

Age: 21

Status: Nun, formerly minor Aragonese nobility (family name: Ximénez)

Position: From convent of Santa Clara in Barcelona, sometimes sent to palace to assist with Queen María's charitable work

Appearance: Habit conceals most features, but glimpses of dark hair, pale skin, delicate features. Moves with quiet grace.

Personality: Deeply pious, took vows at 17 after a religious experience. Gentle, compassionate, but with core of steel. Sees God's hand in everything.

Challenge: This would be catastrophic - she's a bride of Christ, her vows are sacred. Any romantic feeling would be sinful for both. Would force Juan to confront his own humanity vs. his spiritual mission.

Hook: She heard about his offering before the Pope and wants to meet him. Their spiritual conversations could be profound but also dangerous - two people certain of God's will, but in different ways.

Each option creates different tensions:

Options 1 & 4: Politically appropriate but complicated

Options 2 & 3: Sympathetic but socially inappropriate

Option 5: Complete commoner, maximum social barrier

Option 6: Spiritually impossible, maximum internal conflict

Roll 1d6 to determine which woman catches Juan's eye during his time in Barcelona.

I rolled 2 - Isabel.

Back to planning our journey.


Can we maybe aquire more ships for transport? Would we be more safe when we are accompanied by multiple vessels?

Now, back to the practical question about ships and the journey. Juan is asking if acquiring multiple ships would make them safer. This is actually a smart strategic question.

Let me have Rodrigo and Sir Thomas respond to this with practical military/naval considerations.

Rodrigo's eyebrows rise slightly at the question - clearly he hadn't considered this option. He looks to Sir Thomas, who has more naval experience.

Sir Thomas nods thoughtfully. "Your Majesty, that's actually sound military thinking. Multiple ships reduce risk in several ways."

He ticks off points on his fingers:

"First, if one ship is damaged or attacked, you don't lose everything. The relics, treasury, and your person could be distributed across vessels - if corsairs take one, they don't capture it all. Second, multiple ships can defend each other. Three merchant galleys traveling together are much less attractive targets than one alone. Pirates prefer easy prey."

He pauses, considering.

"Third, and perhaps most important - if we hire multiple ships, we control the small fleet. We're not just passengers dependent on one captain's decisions. We could have our own men on each vessel, coordinate our movements, choose our route together."

García adds his perspective: "And it means more swords if we need to fight. Even if the crews are merchants, not warriors, three ships means triple the manpower. That matters in a boarding action."

Rodrigo nods, warming to the idea. "Your Majesty, it would also give us flexibility. If one ship has problems - storms damage it, illness breaks out among the crew - we can transfer to another. We're not trapped with one option."

Sir Thomas continues: "The question is cost and coordination. Three galleys from Barcelona to Seville..." He calculates mentally. "Probably 5,000-6,000 florins total, possibly more if we want quality vessels with experienced crews. And we'd need to ensure they all sail together - that requires coordination, possibly hiring captains who've worked together before."

He strokes his beard thoughtfully.

"There's also the question of what we're protecting and how we divide it. The relics and you, Your Majesty, should obviously be on the flagship - the best and fastest vessel. The treasury could be split across the other ships. We'd need guards distributed across all three vessels."

García points out: "That spreads our fighters thin, Your Majesty. Seven capable men across three ships means maybe two or three per vessel. Each ship becomes more vulnerable individually, even though the fleet is stronger together."

Rodrigo adds: "We'd need to decide command structure too. Who leads each ship's contingent? Marco could command one, Sir Thomas another, García the third with you and me on the flagship. But that separates our experienced fighters."

Sir Thomas nods. "It's a trade-off, Your Majesty. Greater overall security but more complex logistics. And there's another consideration - three ships are more visible than one. We'd attract more attention in every port. Harder to move quietly if that's what you wanted."

He looks at you directly.

"But if your concern is Granada's naval strength, then yes - multiple ships significantly improve your odds of reaching Seville safely. It's sound strategy, just expensive and complicated."

Rodrigo ventures: "Your Majesty, perhaps we could ask your sister? Queen María would know which Barcelona shipping houses are reliable, which captains work well together, what the current costs are. She might even be able to arrange favorable terms through her position."

García adds pragmatically: "And we should still gather intelligence about Granada's fleet. If their galleys aren't actually operating this far north, we might be spending a fortune on extra ships we don't need. But if they are a real threat..." He shrugs. "Then three ships could be the difference between reaching Seville and being captured."

The morning is advancing - you can hear the palace coming fully to life around you. The four new Italian crusaders stand waiting for direction. The banner still rests in the courtyard, catching sunlight.

What do you want to do? Consult with María about ships and Granada's naval activity? Make a decision about the route now? Focus on other matters first while you gather information?

I will petition Aragon to arrange safe travel for us to Sevilla by sea. And maybe I did not make myself clear enough, but I want the four sworn guards of the banner to always be near it at all times. Dividing them over different ships violates this task.


We should gather more intelligence first. For the coming days, we should display the banner in the cathedral. Rodrigo, be ready to accept more crusaders and to judge and train them like we did the first four. Father Hernando, you know what to do when men approach us to join the crusade as well. You have done exactly what I expected so keep up the good work.


Rodrigo, how is the arming our new recruits going?

2. He clarifies that the four guards of the banner (García, Rodrigo, and... wait, Rodrigo is now captain. Let me check who the four guards are now.)
