Juan walks from his throne to shake al-Zaghal's hand — shocking the court — but firmly refuses the offer, citing the papal mandate as non-negotiable. He offers conversion as the only alternative. Al-Zaghal respectfully declines, warning that Granada now commands 20,000 soldiers with Maghrebi warriors, Egyptian gold, and Ottoman cannon. He departs noting that Juan's promise to protect surrendered Muslims is 'unexpected and will be remembered.' The diplomatic option is closed; war is inevitable.

exchanges.text:
This is frustrating. But lets not get ahead of ourselves.


Lets focus on bringing them in first and stabilize the realm. 
Lets meet with the nobles in the city this evening. I can confirm the order for their arrest. Can you set this in motion?


Lets now meet with the delegation from Grenada. Or is there something else we need to adress now?

Álvaro visibly relaxes, glad to move away from talk of executions. "You're right. One step at a time. I'll have the nobles assembled in the Alcázar's great hall by sunset - that gives us about four hours. The Archbishop of Toledo will be there, which adds weight."

He moves toward the door, then turns back. "The Granadan delegation... Juan, before you meet them, you should know what they've already shown publicly. They've brought gifts worth at least 20,000 dinars - silks, manuscripts, jeweled weapons. They've been praying openly at their residence, but also visiting our churches, speaking respectfully of Christianity. Their leader, Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal, is no fool. He's been building sympathy."

"They're staying at the Casa de los Abades, the old merchant palace. Shall I send word you'll receive them here in the Torre del Oro, or would you prefer the formal throne room at the Alcázar?"

Álvaro pauses. "Also... Fray Hernando should probably be present. A Granadan peace offer versus a crusade bull - the spiritual implications are significant. And maybe Sir Thomas? He's fought Muslims before, might catch military details we'd miss."

"One more thing," he adds. "The Granadans certainly have spies. By tonight, they'll know you've confirmed the arrest warrant for the Infantes. They'll see Castile as divided, weak. They might adjust their offer accordingly - or try to exploit our division."

He waits for your decision. "Where do you want to receive them, and who should be present?"

I shall take my seat in Alcazar. I will have the papal bull and the banner there on full display.


I shall go there now.

Juan wants to receive the Granadan delegation in the Alcázar throne room with the papal bull and sacred banner on display. This is a power move - showing strength and divine authority rather than meeting them privately. Let me set this scene appropriately.

He's choosing to make this a formal state reception rather than a private negotiation. The timing is interesting - he's doing this before the evening meeting with nobles about the Infantes. 

I should:
1. Describe the preparation of the throne room
2. Set up the impressive display of the sacred items
3. Show the Granadan delegation's arrival and reaction
4. Begin the diplomatic encounter

This is a significant moment - the first meeting between Juan and Granada since he received the crusade bull.

Álvaro nods approvingly. "A formal reception. Good. Let them see the full majesty of Castile and God's mandate. I'll send word immediately and have the throne room prepared."

The Alcázar Throne Room - Early Afternoon

Within an hour, the great throne room of Seville's Alcázar has been transformed. You sit on the throne of Castile, wearing clean white garments with your father's sword across your lap. Behind you, mounted on a tall stand, the white banner blazes in the afternoon sunlight streaming through high windows. The gold reliquary of the True Cross and silver reliquary of Saint James's bone catch the light like stars.

To your right stands Fray Hernando in his simple Hieronymite robes. To your left, Álvaro de Luna in the rich dress of the Constable. Sir Thomas Beaumont stands with the guard, his scarred face impassive. Rodrigo and García flank the banner itself, hands on sword hilts.

The papal bull, with its heavy lead seal, rests on a cushion on a small table beside the throne - visible to all who approach.

Courtiers line the walls. Word has spread quickly, and perhaps sixty nobles and churchmen have gathered to witness this meeting. The Archbishop of Toledo stands among them, watching carefully.

The great doors open. A herald announces: "The embassy of the Sultan of Granada!"

The Granadan Delegation Enters

Twelve men enter in formation. Their leader, Abu Abdullah al-Zaghal, is perhaps fifty, with intelligent dark eyes and a carefully groomed gray beard. He wears rich but not ostentatious robes of deep blue silk. His companions include scribes, two who are clearly military observers, and one who might be a scholar or imam.

They carry three ornate chests - their gifts.

As they advance down the long hall, you see the moment al-Zaghal notices the banner and relics. His step doesn't falter, but his eyes narrow slightly. When he sees the papal bull, his expression becomes even more careful.

He stops at the appropriate distance and bows - correctly, respectfully, but not subserviently.

"Your Majesty Juan, King of Castile and León, I bring greetings from my lord Muhammad IX, Sultan of Granada, Defender of the Faithful, Lord of Málaga and Almería. May peace be upon this gathering."

His Castilian is flawless, with only the slightest accent.

"My Sultan sends these humble gifts as a token of our desire for continued peace between our realms." He gestures, and his men open the chests, revealing:

Bolts of silk that shimmer like water

An illuminated Quran with covers of gold and ivory (bold to bring to a Christian court)

A sword with a damascene blade and jeweled hilt

An astrolabe of brass and silver, incredibly intricate

Several manuscripts on mathematics and astronomy

Al-Zaghal continues: "My Sultan has heard of Your Majesty's... spiritual journey. We congratulate you on receiving the blessing of your Holy Father. Yet we come to remind you that Granada has been home to Muslims, Christians, and Jews for seven centuries. Many arrangements are possible between men of wisdom."

He pauses, choosing his words carefully. "My Sultan offers this: Double the current tribute, from 50,000 to 100,000 gold dinars annually. Free passage for Christian merchants in our lands. The return of all Christian captives currently held - some 300 souls. Permission for Christian priests to minister to Christians living in Granada. All this, in exchange for continued peace."

"Furthermore," his voice takes on a slightly harder edge, "the Sultan wishes Your Majesty to know that Granada does not stand alone. The Dar al-Islam - the house of Islam - has awakened to our situation. Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt, even the mighty Ottomans have pledged their support. What might have been an easy conquest a year ago would now be a long, bloody war."

"Yet war serves neither of our peoples. The farmers need peace to tend their fields. The merchants need peace for trade. Mothers need peace to raise their children - both Christian and Muslim mothers weep the same tears for dead sons."

He gestures to the illuminated Quran. "That holy book, which I know Your Majesty will not read, speaks of Jesus - whom we call Isa - as a great prophet. It speaks of Mary - Maryam - with reverence. We are not the pagans your ancestors fought. We worship the God of Abraham, as do you."

"My Sultan proposes this: Let us sign a treaty of twenty years' peace. Your Majesty can claim victory - doubled tribute, freed captives, protected Christians. You can focus on the internal matters of Castile." His eyes flicker meaningfully - he knows about the Infantes. "And in twenty years, perhaps our children will find better solutions than sword and blood."

Al-Zaghal steps back. "This is Granada's offer, made in good faith. We come as neighbors seeking peace, not as subjects seeking mercy. What says the King of Castile?"

The throne room is utterly silent. Everyone watches you. The papal bull gleams beside you, the True Cross blazes behind you, and before you stands an intelligent, dignified man offering you everything except the one thing the Pope commanded - the conquest of Granada.

How do you respond?

I stand up from my throne and walk up to the noble Muslim to shake his hand.


I welcome you and thank you for your moving and spirited appeal. We have lived as neighbours for a long time and there is much we can teach one another.


I point to the papal bull.


In fact our holy father has charged me to ensure both Christians and Muslims live peacefully in Grenada and I take this charge very seriously.


But we cannot deny the constant conflicts there have been along our borders. I have come to put an end to those once and for all and end the constant raiding and tention in our lands. Both Muslims and Christians will live peacefully under christian rule.


I let Diego read the Bull in it's entirely where I stress the treatment of converts and the prohibition of plundering. We conclude with the crusade goals, the conversion of mosques to churches, overthrowing of muslim rule and a te deum in Grenada.


You see my friend, you can convert today and you will fall under my protection. But we christians all know - and a spread my arms wide and gesture to the crowd - that such a command from our holy father and our lord binds us. That is why I must respectfully decline your proposal as it is in direct conflict with my sacred charge and I will never violate that. What you propose is impossible and I hope you understand this.


I wish you well, I truly do. May the light of the lord find you and I hope to one day greet you as fellow christian.


If there is nothing further, go home with my blessing.

Juan is taking a firm but respectful stance here. He's:
1. Showing personal respect by walking up and offering to shake hands
2. Acknowledging the peaceful offer 
3. Having the papal bull read in full to show his position is not negotiable
4. Offering conversion as an alternative
5. Being clear but not hostile
6. Essentially ending negotiations firmly but politely

I need to show how al-Zaghal responds to this - he's intelligent and came prepared for this possibility. The nobles watching will have varied reactions. This is a significant moment.

The throne room stirs with whispers as you rise and walk toward the Muslim ambassador. Several courtiers look shocked - a king leaving his throne to greet an infidel? But al-Zaghal's eyes show a flicker of genuine respect as he takes your offered hand firmly.

As Diego reads the papal bull in its entirety - a full twenty minutes of Latin translated to Castilian - you watch al-Zaghal's face. His expression never changes, but his military advisors exchange meaningful glances at certain passages. The promises of protection for converts, the prohibition of plundering, the requirement for peaceful conversion offers before military action - these are not what they expected.

When Diego finishes with "...a Te Deum sung in the cathedral of Granada," the silence is profound.

Al-Zaghal nods slowly. "Your Majesty honors us with plain speech. Let me return the courtesy." His voice carries clearly through the hall. "You offer me protection if I convert today. A generous offer, personally. But I am a Muslim, as my father was, and his father before him. I will die a Muslim, God willing."

He steps back, addressing you but speaking to the entire court. "You say this is a sacred charge that binds you. I understand. We too have sacred duties. And so I must tell you clearly - Granada will resist. Not from hatred of Christ, whom we revere as a prophet. Not from hatred of Christians, many of whom live peacefully in our lands. But because our faith, our law, our way of life is also sacred to us."

The ambassador's voice takes on a different tone - formal, almost ceremonial: "Since you have been plain, let me be also. Granada is not the isolated city it was. Twenty thousand soldiers gather under our banner. The Maghreb sends its finest warriors. Egypt sends gold. The Ottomans send their great cannon. This will not be the easy conquest of a weak neighbor. This will be war between faiths, and such wars are the bloodiest of all."

He gestures to his scribes, who begin packing the gifts. "We will take these back. They were offered in hope of peace. But know this - we also take back word of a young king who treated us with courtesy, who walked from his throne to shake a Muslim's hand, who promises protection for converts rather than slaughter."

"That is... unexpected. And it will be remembered."

Al-Zaghal bows again. "Your Majesty, I suspect we will meet again, though next time it may be across a battlefield rather than a throne room. I pray that when that day comes, we both remember this moment - when two men of different faiths spoke honestly and parted without hatred."

He turns to go, then pauses. "One thing more. The internal troubles of Castile are known to us. Some in Granada counsel that we should attack while you face the Infantes. But my Sultan is honorable. We will not strike while you settle your house. But once you march south with that banner, once you cross our frontier - then we will fight with everything we have."

"Go with your God, Juan of Castile. You will need Him."

The delegation withdraws in perfect order, taking their gifts. As the doors close behind them, the throne room erupts in discussion.

The Archbishop of Toledo approaches the throne. "Your Majesty... that was remarkably handled. Firm but not insulting. Though I confess, shaking his hand..."

Several younger nobles are energized, talking of crusade and glory. Others look thoughtful - al-Zaghal's warnings about Granada's strength clearly registered.

Álvaro appears at your elbow. "Well done. You showed strength without giving them cause for immediate war. And his promise not to attack during our internal troubles - that's valuable time."

He lowers his voice. "The nobles are assembled for tonight. After what they just witnessed, confirming the arrest order for the Infantes will seem like the natural next step in asserting your authority. Shall we proceed?"

Fray Hernando has been silent throughout, but now speaks quietly: "That man would have been a valuable Christian. But forced conversion is no conversion at all. You did right to let him leave in peace."

Next up is meeting with the nobles of the city where I will demand the infantes surrender themselves to face trial.

The Noble Assembly at the Alcázar

Seville, September 28, 1430 - Evening

The great hall of Seville's Alcázar fills with nervous energy as nobles, church officials, and city representatives gather. Word spread quickly through the city: the King will address the matter of the Infantes tonight.

The Audience (~80 people assembled):

Royal Supporters (~25 nobles):

Álvaro de Luna stands near the throne, composed but showing strain from the failed arrest

Your secret cabinet members scattered throughout: Juan de Daza, Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Lope de Barrientos, Íñigo López de Mendoza (younger), Rodrigo Manrique

Several loyal noble houses from Andalusia

Bishop of Seville and clergy clearly on your side

Neutral Observers (~45 nobles and officials):

Masters of Calatrava and Alcántara (the Military Orders still uncommitted)

Representatives from major cities: Burgos, Toledo, Córdoba

Minor and middling nobility watching carefully

Merchants and guild representatives

Infantes Sympathizers (~10 nobles):

Supporters who backed the failed rebellion

Looking defiant but nervous

Master of Santiago (Luis de Guzmán) - the one Military Order supporting the Infantes

A few northern nobles with Aragonese connections

The Atmosphere:

Torches and candles illuminate faces showing worry, calculation, fear

Armed guards at every entrance - both royal guards and private retinues

Everyone knows about the failed arrest at Arévalo

Many received letters from the Infantes claiming the arrest orders were "unlawful persecution"

Your 62 white-clad crusaders are visible outside the hall, a new presence that draws many eyes

You sit on the throne with the papal bull in its sealed case beside you. The white banner with the True Cross and Santiago's bone stands behind you, clearly visible to all.

Álvaro steps forward and announces: "His Majesty Juan II, by the grace of God King of Castile and León, will now address this assembly."

The hall falls silent. Every eye turns to you.

How do you wish to proceed, Your Majesty?

You could:

Give a formal speech about royal authority and the Infantes' rebellion

Speak more informally, addressing specific concerns

Focus on the crusade and papal backing as the main message

Confront the Infantes' supporters directly

Address the failed arrest and what happens next

Something else entirely

What do you say or do?

I am about to perform an action. My goal is to increase my support, to weaken the infantes influence and power.


My dear nobles, welcome and thank you for coming. Much has happened the last months and I understand you are eager to hear about my pilgrimage. I will recount all events in a moment but first, I want to adress the rebellion that is currently under way against the crown. The infantes must surrender themselves to face trial. This is well known and the longer they don't the longer uncertainty and instability in the realm continues. They will answer for the damage they have caused and their judgement shall be just and fair.


The infantes stand accused among other crimes of spreading misinformation about events and about my person. I regret that anyone may have believed these lies to be true, but I do not blame them. There is time for them to reaffirm their trust in me and my rule and I bear no ill will against anyone. I thank those who's faith in me has remained strong even during my absence. My fight is with the infantes alone and anyone helping or serving them rebels against not only me, the crown but also against the sacred charge I have recieved in Rome. I cannot fight Grenada while rebels are stabbing me in the back.


Now, I will recount events starting with me installing a regency council to rule in my stead during my pilgrimage. As you know, I wanted to include the infantes in this and I entrusted them with half my council seats. I felt I was being more than fair to them, giving them a lot of influence. An opportunity to serve the realm. So I left, safe in the knowledge the realm was stable and secure in my absence.


A few days into my journey I felt a special calling for the first time. A pull or feeling I should return home and retrieve my father's sword. I did not know it at the time, but this desicion was more important than I could even imagine. After much prayer, I sent my main party ahead and with a few guards I rode back home quickly and arrived just when the first council was taking place. I overheard the infantes already planting the seeds of rebellion by replacing key positions and even proposing a permanent council to effectively rule in my stead. The other two members of the council are present here today and they can as witnesses attest to these actions.


I give both the bishop and Mendoza a chance to give their testimony.


I immediately walked in and removed infante Juan from the council. Still wanting peace in my realm, I kept Enrique. A sign of trust that was again perhaps too naive. I dismissed Juan and threatened him if he refused. An action I regret, angry as I was and a sinner before God.


I then left for Santiago where another feeling struck me. I felt certain I should travel all the way to holy Rome and petition the holy See to grant me a crusade against Grenada. It seemed folly at the time, my pilgrimage was not meant to go on for so long, but I again felt certain and I set off to Rome. Along the way I met many people and had many inspired and blessed persons, some of which wrote letters of recommendation, attesting to my faith and my sincerity.


I give a chance for all letters to be read and passed around for inspection.


When I arrived in Italy, I inspected my fathers sword carefully for the first time and read that it read "Non nobis Domine". Words that have come to mean so much to me and others. I started to feel more and more certain but there was still more to come.


I pass around my sword so everyone can inspect it and read the inscription.


When I arrived in Rome I met with Orsini and we discussed why I was in Rome and what I wanted. Later that night, a final feeling came over me. I felt so certain about what I should do next, but was also terrified. I tried to let my soul find comfort in the council of my confessor as I so often do but I was unable to bring into words what I was about to do. I have seldom felt so alone in my struggles before God my friends, especially since I knew what I was about to do and that I was absolutely going to do it. I will let witnesses describe what happened during my meeting with the holy father.


I let witnesses describe events and I let the letter of Orsini be read and passed around.


I then let the entire papal bull be read, including the passage that includes my actions during my audience with the pope, establishing what happened beyond any doubt hopefully.


With support I started my long journey back home. I raised my banner for the first time in Florance and then went on to Barcelona where I recieved much support and was able to see my dear sister again after many years. She is in good health and brings her greetings to this court, remembering her roots as a Castillian noble woman.


This brings me here with you today where we ask ourselves what to do next. Can I count on your support to face the challenges ahead?


Determine my chance for success using the standard method without describing the outcome yet.

1. **Juan's stated goal**: Increase support, weaken Infantes' influence
2. **His approach**: 
   - Firmly demand Infantes surrender for trial

   - Recount his journey with evidence and witnesses

Let me assess the probability factors:

**FACTORS FAVORING SUCCESS:**

1. **Physical Evidence**: He has overwhelming documentation
   - Papal bull (official, sealed, authenticated)
   - Letters from Archbishop of Zaragoza, Cardinal Orsini, others
   - Father's sword with inscription
   - Witnesses present who saw events

2. **Papal Authority**: The crusade bull is the nuclear option
   - Pope Martin V personally blessed him

   - This is the biggest advantage

3. **The Infantes' Failed Rebellion**: They actually did try to seize power
   - Archbishop of Toledo and Marquis de Santillana were on that council
   - They can confirm the Infantes' plotting
   - The Infantes refused lawful arrest orders
   - They withdrew to fortresses - looks like guilt

4. **Álvaro Successfully Defended**: Kingdom didn't collapse
   - All major cities stayed loyal
   - Royal administration intact
   - This proves Juan's government was functioning

5. **Narrative Control**: Juan controls the room right now
   - He has the floor
   - All evidence supports his version
   - Infantes aren't present to defend themselves

6. **Amnesty Offer**: "I bear no ill will" to supporters
   - Gives neutrals and even some Infantes supporters an out
   - Can switch sides without admitting guilt
   - Politically smart

7. **The 62 Crusaders**: Visible, disciplined force
   - Shows he's building something real
   - White tabards with red crosses distinctive
   - Religious symbolism powerful

8. **Religious Framing**: This isn't just politics anymore
   - It's about a sacred crusade
   - Opposing Juan means opposing the Pope's will
   - Very powerful in medieval context

**FACTORS AGAINST SUCCESS:**

The failed arrest attempt represents a significant challenge to Juan's credibility. This setback potentially undermines his political standing and reveals vulnerabilities in his initial strategy. The inability to execute a direct arrest suggests potential weaknesses in his political and military control, which could erode confidence among potential supporters.

Alfonso V's military threat introduces substantial external pressure. This intervention by the Aragonese king creates a complex diplomatic landscape where potential allies might hesitate, fearing broader regional conflict. The threat of war could paralyze decision-making and fragment potential support for Juan's crusade.

Juan's lack of an heir presents a critical succession problem. Nobles might view supporting him as a risky investment, potentially preferring alternative lineages that offer more stable long-term prospects. This uncertainty could significantly undermine his political capital and strategic positioning.

The economic and human costs of potential conflict weigh heavily on nobles' calculations. Many regional leaders benefit from existing arrangements and view a crusade as potentially destabilizing. Their self-interest prioritizes maintaining current power structures over embracing potentially disruptive military campaigns.

Religious and cultural tensions add another layer of complexity. Juan's apparent tolerance, symbolized by diplomatic interactions with Muslim representatives, might alienate more conservative factions. These underlying cultural dynamics could create internal friction and challenge his broader political narrative.

Regional differences further complicate Juan's strategic landscape. Northern nobles, with distinct priorities and interests, may remain detached from Granada-focused initiatives, revealing the fragmented nature of potential support. The papal bull's significance cannot be overstated in medieval European politics. Pope Martin V's personal endorsement of Juan, including the True Cross fragment and crusade commission, creates immense ecclesiastical pressure that's challenging to resist without severe religious consequences.

The failed arrest weakens Juan's position, yet his strategic response demonstrates political acumen. With compelling evidence from high-ranking witnesses like the Archbishop of Toledo and Marquis de Santillana, Juan effectively exposes the Infantes' plotting.

His amnesty offer provides a politically elegant escape route for wavering nobles. While self-interest and caution prevail, the combination of papal authority, physical evidence, and a face-saving diplomatic option tilts the probability of success in Juan's favor.

The narrative dynamics strongly favor Juan, despite the prestige damage from the unsuccessful arrest attempt. The papal blessing fundamentally reframes the conflict, making open opposition nearly untenable for most nobles.

Anticipated outcomes suggest a moderate but meaningful shift: approximately 20-30% of neutral nobles might support Juan, gradually isolating the Infantes without guaranteeing total victory. The papal bull opens a strategic pathway to strengthening his Royal Council position.

Describe the outcome of the events using this result.

The papal bull is powerful, the evidence is strong, but something goes wrong. Let me think about what would realistically happen in a failure scenario:

1. The speech is good, the evidence is compelling
2. BUT the nobles don't shift their positions much

The Noble Assembly - A Respectful Resistance

Seville, September 28, 1430 - Evening

The Testimonies

Archbishop Juan Martínez de Contreras (Archbishop of Toledo) rises first when you invite him to testify. His voice is measured, careful:

"I bear witness to what His Majesty describes. At that first council meeting in May, I was present. Infante Juan did indeed propose... substantial changes to the regency structure. The young king's return was unexpected, and his removal of Infante Juan from the council was... within his royal prerogative."

The Archbishop sits. His testimony is technically supportive, but delivered with visible discomfort. He doesn't want to anger the Infantes or their powerful brother Alfonso V.

Íñigo López de Mendoza the Elder (Marquis de Santillana) stands next. A more forceful voice:

"The Infantes discussed making the regency permanent. I heard it with my own ears. They spoke of moderating His Majesty's 'enthusiasm' upon his return. The king's account is accurate."

Better. But Mendoza also adds: "Though I must note - the younger Infante, Enrique, has served honorably on the regency council since. He is not his brother."

The Documents Circulate

Your father's sword passes from hand to hand. Nobles examine the inscription: Non Nobis Domine. Some touch it reverently. Others study it skeptically, as if checking whether the words might be recently added.

The letters from Toulouse, Avignon, and Cardinal Orsini make their rounds. Nobles read them carefully. You see nods, impressed expressions. The Cardinal's letter describing your papal audience draws particular attention - Orsini is known throughout Europe, his words carry weight.

Then the papal bull is read aloud.

The chamber falls utterly silent as the reader progresses through the Latin, translating key passages into Castilian. When he reaches the section describing your act before Pope Martin V - the complete renunciation, kneeling naked, the offering of everything - gasps and whispers ripple through the hall.

Several clergy make the sign of the cross. Some nobles look genuinely moved.

But others exchange glances that say: Is this piety or madness?

The Response Begins

When you finish your address and ask for their support, there is a long silence.

Then the Master of Calatrava stands. He's a powerful man, head of one of the three great Military Orders, and crucially - he's been neutral throughout this crisis.

"Your Majesty, no one here questions the authenticity of your papal bull. It is... extraordinary. The Pope's blessing upon you is clear. Your pilgrimage and its results are remarkable."

He pauses. The whole hall waits.

"But Your Majesty, we must speak of practical matters. You ordered the Infantes arrested for rebellion. This was your right as king. But..." he chooses his words carefully, "...the arrest failed. They refused to surrender. They withdrew to their fortresses. And King Alfonso of Aragon has made his position clear - any harm to his brothers means war."

Murmurs of agreement ripple through the neutral faction.

"You ask if you can count on our support to face challenges ahead. But which challenge, Your Majesty? The crusade against Granada? Or civil war against the Infantes? Because we cannot fight both. We do not have the strength for both."

A merchant representative from Burgos stands next, emboldened by the Master's frankness:

"Your Majesty, the crusade will cost fortunes. Lives. Years of campaigning. Meanwhile, our trade with Granada is profitable. The tribute they pay enriches the treasury. Is it wise to destroy this arrangement for... for what? So we can spend decades bleeding ourselves against their mountain fortresses?"

The Crucial Moment

Count Fadrique Enríquez, a powerful Andalusian noble who has been loyal to the crown, rises. You expect support. Instead:

"Your Majesty, I believe your account of events. I believe the Infantes plotted against you. I believe the Pope blessed you. But..."

He looks around the room, gathering courage to say what many are thinking.

"Your Majesty, you have no heir. You are eighteen, unmarried, no children. If something happens to you - in battle, by illness, by accident - who inherits? The Infantes or their line. We would be fighting against our potential future kings."

"You ask us to commit to a crusade of years, perhaps decades. To help you arrest princes of Aragon. To risk war on two fronts. But you give us no security about succession, no promise of stability, no..." he struggles for the word, "...no certainty that this won't all collapse if you fall from a horse next month."

The silence that follows is crushing.

The Final Response

Álvaro de Luna looks stricken. He steps forward to speak, but you see it in the room - the damage is done.

One by one, nobles begin to respond to your question. The pattern becomes clear:

The Already-Loyal (~25 nobles):

Pledge continued support

But with visible worry about the complications raised

Álvaro, your cabinet members, Bishop of Seville, loyal Andalusian houses

They were with you before; they're still with you

But they look concerned

The Neutrals (~45 nobles):

Express respect for papal authority

Acknowledge the Infantes' rebellion

But make no concrete pledges

"We will watch how matters develop"

"We must consult with our houses"

"The crusade is a worthy goal, but the timing..."

They applaud your piety but commit to nothing

The Infantes' Supporters (~10 nobles):

Master of Santiago speaks: "Your Majesty, the Infantes deserve to face their accusers in person, not be arrested by your favorite." (He means Álvaro)

"They are princes of Aragon. This matter must be resolved diplomatically."

They're defiant but notably don't leave the hall

Even they seem uncomfortable openly opposing a papal crusader

The Aftermath

When the assembly concludes an hour later, you've gained perhaps three or four nobles who shift from neutral to supportive. Not nothing, but far from the decisive swing you hoped for.

The Master of Alcántara approaches you privately afterward: "Your Majesty, I mean no disrespect. What you accomplished in Rome is extraordinary. But we need to see the Infantes dealt with before we commit to crusade. Show us you can handle rebels in Castile, then we'll follow you to Granada."

Juan de Daza, your treasury official from the secret cabinet, whispers to you as nobles file out: "Your Majesty, they believe everything you said. They just don't believe it matters. The failed arrest looms too large."

Status Update

Noble Alignment (after the assembly):

Supporting Crown: 32-35% (up from 30-35% - minimal gain)

Supporting Infantes: 15-20% (unchanged)

Neutral/Waiting: 50% (down slightly but still majority)

The Problem Identified:

The nobles heard your story. They believe it. They're impressed by the papal bull. But they're paralyzed by practical concerns:

The failed arrest makes you look weak

Alfonso V's threat of war

Your lack of an heir

The impossibility of fighting Infantes AND Granada simultaneously

Economic interests tied to current Granada arrangement

Álvaro's Assessment (in your private chambers afterward):

"Your Majesty, you gave them everything - miracles, papal blessing, physical proof. And they still won't move. This isn't about evidence. It's about fear. They're afraid to commit to either side until they see who will win."

He looks exhausted. "The November Council is six weeks away. We need to give them something concrete before then. Not just spiritual authority - actual power. Either we break the Infantes somehow, or we make peace with them. We can't go to the Royal Council with this standoff unresolved."

Your Majesty, the evening grows late. Your 62 crusaders wait outside, your relics are secure, but your political position has barely improved despite your best efforts.

What do you wish to do next?

events.summary: Stung by the failed noble address, Juan and Álvaro strategize late into the night. They decide on three major moves: (1) pursue a Portuguese marriage for Juan — a naval power with no stake in the Aragonese dispute; (2) send a letter to Alfonso V of Aragon offering safe conduct for the Infantes to attend the November Royal Council, support for Alfonso's Italian ambitions, and a hint at future meeting; (3) publicly announce the safe conduct to shift narrative from 'tyrannical arrest' to 'fair trial.' The letter to Alfonso is drafted that night, including papal backing references, and dispatched by fastest ship the next morning with gifts (sword, Castilian war horse).

And I understand their position better now. I need an heir as soon as possible. Suggestions?

1. His feelings of being crushed - Álvaro should be sympathetic but also honest
2. The heir/marriage question - this is urgent and practical
3. The letter from Alfonso V - let me think what that would say
4. Displaying the banner publicly in Seville like Barcelona/Florence

I should have this be a conversation, not a monologue. Let Juan and Álvaro talk back and forth.

Private Council with Álvaro

Royal Chambers, Alcázar of Seville - Late Evening, September 28, 1430

Álvaro dismisses the servants and closes the door. For the first time in months, you're alone with your closest advisor, the man who held your kingdom together during your absence.

He pours two cups of wine and hands you one. His face shows the strain of the past months - new lines around his eyes, grey creeping into his dark hair.

"Your Majesty... Juan..." He uses your name, which he rarely does even in private. "You did everything right. Your speech was perfect. The evidence overwhelming. Any reasonable person would be convinced."

He sits heavily. "But nobles aren't reasonable when they're afraid. And right now, they're terrified."

He drinks. "You feel crushed. I understand. But you need to hear something: you've been gone four months. I've been here, watching this unfold. The Infantes' rebellion failing should have destroyed them. But instead, when you tried to arrest them and they refused, something shifted. Nobles started asking: 'If the King can't arrest rebels, what can he do?'"

He meets your eyes. "That's what we're fighting now. Not their loyalty to the Infantes - their doubt about your power to act."

The Marriage Question

Álvaro's expression shifts to something more calculating, more political. This is his strength.

"An heir. Yes. Immediately. You're eighteen - you should have been married two years ago. Your father's death and the regency chaos delayed it, but we can't wait longer."

He stands, pacing. "Let me think through options..."

"The Aragonese Alliance":
"Alfonso V's wife is your sister María, but they have no children after fifteen years. He might be open to another connection. He has cousins - there's Leonor of Alburquerque, about your age, connected to the royal house. A marriage there would force Alfonso to choose: support his brothers in rebellion, or accept his new brother-in-law the King?"

Álvaro pauses. "But it looks like capitulation. Like you're begging Alfonso for peace by marrying into his family. The Infantes would see it as weakness."

"The Portuguese Option":
"King João I has granddaughters. Portugal is wealthy, stable, focused on African exploration rather than Iberian politics. Clean alliance, no internal complications. Princess Isabel of Portugal is about your age, well-educated, by all accounts intelligent."

"Advantage: neutral. Doesn't strengthen one Castilian faction over another. Doesn't anger Aragon. Brings Portuguese gold and naval expertise."

"Disadvantage: doesn't solve your immediate Infantes problem. Doesn't give you powerful allies within Castile."

To Our Most Esteemed Cousin, Alfonso, by the Grace of God King of Aragon, Valencia, Majorca, Sardinia, and Corsica, Duke of Athens and Neopatria, Count of Barcelona, Ruler in Sicily,

From Juan, by the Grace of God King of Castile and León,

Greetings in Christ Our Lord, and wishes for Your Majesty's health, prosperity, and success in all your righteous endeavors.

Opening - Acknowledgment and Respect

We write in response to Your Majesty's letter of the third of September, which reached us after our return from pilgrimage. We acknowledge your concerns regarding your brothers, the Infantes Juan and Enrique, with the seriousness and respect such matters deserve.

We recognize that these princes are your blood, sons of the late King Fernando I of blessed memory, and members of the illustrious royal house of Aragon. Their station commands respect, and their relationship to Your Majesty adds weight to all considerations.

The Safe Conduct Grant

After much prayer and consultation, we have determined to grant your brothers full and honorable safe conduct to attend the Royal Council of Castile, which shall convene in our city of Seville on the eighth day of November in this year of Our Lord 1430.

This safe conduct guarantees:

Safe travel to Seville from wherever they may reside

Security of person during the proceedings of the Council

Full opportunity to present their case before the assembled nobility of our realm

Safe departure from Seville when the Council concludes

Throughout these proceedings, we commit that the Infantes shall be treated with all dignity, respect, and consideration befitting princes of royal blood. They shall have freedom to speak, to call witnesses, to answer charges, and to defend themselves according to proper legal process.

Whatever judgment may emerge from the Council's deliberations, we assure Your Majesty that any consequences will reflect their royal status. We seek justice, not vengeance; resolution, not persecution.

The Papal Context

We must inform Your Majesty of developments during our pilgrimage, as they bear upon all matters concerning our realm and its relations with Christian kingdoms.

By the grace of God and through His mysterious providence, we were led to Rome itself, where we were granted audience with His Holiness Pope Martin V. What transpired in that sacred meeting we leave to the accounts of witnesses - Cardinal Giordano Orsini among them - but the result is clear and documented:

His Holiness granted us a plenary crusade bull for the completion of the Reconquista and the recovery of the Kingdom of Granada for Christendom. We were commissioned as Supreme Commander of this holy endeavor and blessed with relics of profound significance - a fragment of the True Cross itself and a bone of the blessed Saint James.

We mention this not to boast, but so Your Majesty understands the sacred obligation we now carry. The completion of Iberian Christian unity is no longer merely our personal ambition - it is a charge from the Vicar of Christ himself. This shapes all our considerations and decisions.

We pray Your Majesty will understand that we must order our realm's affairs in service of this holy commission. Internal divisions weaken not just Castile, but all of Christendom's capacity to advance Christ's kingdom.

The Barcelona Experience

We had the great pleasure during our journey of spending time in your magnificent city of Barcelona. The warmth with which your subjects received us, the generosity they showed toward our crusading mission, and the support they pledged moved us deeply.

We were also blessed to see our beloved sister, your esteemed wife Queen María, after many years of separation. She spoke with great affection of Your Majesty and with hope for continued harmony between our royal houses. Her wisdom and grace were evident in all our conversations.

This experience in Barcelona reminded us of a simple truth: the peoples of Castile and Aragon are not natural enemies. We share faith, language, culture, history, and the Iberian homeland. When we cooperate, remarkable things become possible. When we conflict, we both diminish.

The Italian Opportunity

We have observed with great interest Your Majesty's pursuit of your rightful claims in the Kingdom of Naples and your efforts to establish Aragonese influence throughout Italy and the Mediterranean.

These are worthy ambitions that serve not only your dynasty but the broader interests of Christian kingdoms in that vital region. A strong, stable Aragonese presence in Italy provides counterweight to other powers and advances Christian civilization in the Mediterranean world.

We wish Your Majesty to know: a unified and secure Castile, properly ordered under our crown and dedicated to completing the Reconquista, could be a valuable partner in your Mediterranean endeavors.

Once our internal matters are resolved and the crusade against Granada is launched, we would have the capacity to provide:

Military forces for Italian campaigns

Naval support in the Mediterranean

Financial assistance for your righteous claims

Diplomatic backing with His Holiness and other Christian monarchs

We are prepared to discuss specific terms and commitments when the time is appropriate.

The Strategic Vision

Your Majesty, we believe our kingdoms face a choice that will shape the next generation:

Do we expend our resources, our blood, and our energy in internal Iberian conflicts? Or do we unite our considerable strengths toward the great tasks that await - for you in Italy, for us in Granada?

The Infantes matter has created tension between our realms. We do not minimize this. There are legitimate grievances and concerns on multiple sides. But we propose that this need not define our relationship.

We offer a path forward:

Your brothers receive fair hearing and treatment befitting their station

Castilian internal matters are resolved according to Castilian law and the judgment of our assembled nobility

Our kingdoms build partnership focused on our respective strategic goals

We support your Italian ambitions; you respect our sacred crusading commission

This allows both of us to achieve what we truly seek, rather than remaining entangled in conflicts that serve neither kingdom's interests.

Personal Meeting Proposal

We would be deeply honored to meet Your Majesty in person to discuss these matters directly and to strengthen the bonds between our crowns. The relationship between kings is built not just through letters and ambassadors, but through personal acquaintance and understanding.

We recognize Your Majesty is currently engaged in vital work in Naples, and we ourselves face numerous duties in preparation for the November Council and the crusade beyond. Therefore, we propose that we meet at whatever time and place Your Majesty finds most convenient - whether in Italy, in Aragon, in Castile, or in neutral territory - when our respective duties permit.

Such a meeting could forge partnership that benefits both our realms for decades to come.

Closing

Your Majesty, we write with genuine desire for peace, partnership, and mutual prosperity between Aragon and Castile. We grant your brothers safe conduct and fair treatment because it is both just and wise. We offer support for your Italian ambitions because we see opportunity for cooperation. We propose personal meeting because we value the relationship between our houses.

The matter of your brothers' actions during our absence must be addressed - this we cannot ignore, for a king who tolerates rebellion invites chaos. But how it is addressed, and what follows after, remains to be determined. We prefer resolution that serves both our kingdoms' interests rather than conflict that weakens us both.

We await Your Majesty's response with hope and with prayers for your success, health, and wisdom.

May God guide us both toward decisions that honor Him, serve our peoples, and advance Christian civilization.

Written at our city of Seville, this twenty-ninth day of September, in the year of Our Lord 1430,

Juan II, by the Grace of God, King of Castile and León
